job_title: Cancer Information Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Liked the job, the work was fulfilling, and Fred Hutch is cool

review_title: I only stayed to get a publication because it wasn't a worthwhile enough job to stay long term.
pros: The work is interesting and pretty innovative.
cons:
If you don't have a PhD as a scientist, no one will ever listen to your suggestions. Everyone below PIs are chronically overworked, underpaid, under-appreciated, and are in desperate need of unionization which will never happen because Fred Hutch has a long history of intense and harsh union busting.

During COVID they laid off their entire philanthropy department and then had the nerve to send out an email to the remaining employees asking the rest of us to consider donating money to those who were just laid off. 

Their diversity department is just for publicity and are constantly stopped from being effective. The Hutch hiring managers have dismissed great candidates, all non-Caucasian, because they "might not fit in with the culture". 

There are antiquated octogenarians who refuse to retire and instead perpetuate their ridiculous and toxic expectations. Their great reputation is gained off of the backs of the underpaid. 

Take a look at their board of directors and count how many diverse candidates there are. Lower staff are constantly thwarted from promotion and reasonable pay by a concerted effort of the upper management. They call what would normally be called the cost of living raise (3%) a merit raise. This way they're able to deny employees even this. If you're going to work in this field in this area, make sure your employee is the UW. They're unionized.

review_title: Possibility of flexible hours, however pay is below industry standard

cons: Pay is kind of below industry standard. No bonus and only minimal pay raise a year that is hard to keep up with inflation. No room for career advancement, pretty much it is a terminal position

review_title: A dead end for career path
pros: Work life balance is good. But at what cost? No transparency or 1:1 when an employee tries to move ahead in career path and seeks feedback. Only appreciation you get after working 60h weeks is team celebration with pizza. Team managers basically relay that salaried employees can be exploited without any bonus/comp time off. Only bonus you get is $10 Starbucks coupon every 1-2 year.
cons: No split level meetings. People are always busy to put out immediate fires and move along the next project. Poor people management which leads to a huge turnover in all teams specially with biotech blooming in Greater Seattle area. No 1:1 with skip level and no career advancement for mid-level employees. Entry level employee has to wait at least 4-5 years before they can get a promotion. Open jobs are not being back filled. If there are candidates, the jobs are taken down from the website. (I am not sure if this is to save money for the company but it leads to burn out existing employees).

pros: Maybe good for an introvert who doesnt care if they’re worked to the bone and at risk of injury?
cons: Worked with hazardous chemicals on a daily basis with little to no training or hazard pay, or explanation of what way things would be dangerous. Had to look it up on my own time. Was told the lab’s projects depended on me doing my job perfectly, and was laid into when I made my first mistake almost a year into the job. Told I was jeapordizing the integrity of their years long study. When I asked for better training, especially with hazardous materials (I got almost none, only a small card with a list of ingredients/instructions) to support their expectations of me I was derided for bothering them when they had “more important work to be doing.” Like is my work integral to your study or not? Enough so that I get berated when I made one human mistake with no consequences, but not enough so that I get training. Got snapped at and told no when I asked for supervision handling an extremely flammable/explosive canister. And all that to get paid *minimum wage*. What a joke, if I had any money I would sue.

review_title: Toxic culture:  no PHD, no pay
pros: Good benefits, flexible work hours, good cause. Great place to make connections.
cons: I made the mistake of coming in at a lower salary than I wanted and hoping that I would be promoted over the years. Instead what ensues was a series of lies made to make me think that I was on track for career growth but would never come to fruition. My manager would often promise me things like reducing my hours but keeping my salary the same to make up for the fact that the promised raises never came, but then HR would get wind of that and tell me I was breaking rules and deny me raises even though my supervisor approved them. If you want a promotion, it is up to you to find hidden job descriptions for titles and research your peer’s pay and experience to argue your case. If you don’t have a PHD it doesn’t matter how much experience you have, someone with a masters/PhD and far less experience will always be paid more. If you want a raise you just need to get a new job in another department because it will never otherwise.

pros: Nice view of Lake Union.
cons: I was truly shocked that a well-regarded institution like Fred Hutch had such a poorly managed central (campus) IT department. The main probably I saw was inexperienced, unqualified rookie management. Most of the management staff has no previous management experience, and little or no IT experience. It's the blind leading the blind. Shockingly bad decision-making is the norm. And it's clear from the infrastructure and legacy software that bad decision making has prevailed for years. The place is really a mess - they literally don't know what they're doing. There is no knowledge or experience managing IT projects or personnel. Very frustrating place to work.

review_title: Great place to work but lots of management euphemisms and misdirection
pros: Generally good salaries, best benefits I've ever seen, and respectful and sociable work environment.
cons:
Management likes to yank employees around on issues with euphemisms and constant promises of making working groups, policy committees, and exploratory panels etc. for things like remote work, which is insanely popular among the workforce. Their initial response to the pandemic was to institute a pay freeze and let go of employees at the same time as special covid funding was streaming in. 

So, while pay and benefits are good, other issues that really concern employees like raises, promotions, work-from-home, and getting consistent support during covid have generally been dismissed, ignored, or kicked down the road.

review_title: Horrible turnover rates and apathetic management
pros:
Interesting research
Fun coworkers to commiserate with -- specifically non-managers
Flexible schedules
Diverse fields of study
Attempts to work on diversity, equity, and inclusion.
cons:
They don't really treat their research associates, technicians, postdocs, or grad students like people. They exist solely to pump out data, and are often uncredited for their work.

Low pay could be reasonably tolerated if they followed their own rules for pay raises and if they gave credit where credit is due

Huge turnover rates means loss of productivity, loss of research, and wasted time constantly training new employees. Over 75% of my lab were replaced over the course of 2 years. 

Was told to lie about hours worked because they didn't want to pay overtime

HR is well meaning but completely ineffectual

Complete lack of transparency in terms of careers, promotions, and salaries

PIs give employees the run-around when asking for raises-- the cost of living raise isn't called that and isn't mandatory. It's considered a merit raise and can be denied at any point in time

"Yearly reviews" didn't happen-- as such even merit raises were often delayed-- often times they did not back pay

PIs hold way too much power and often are unaudited. Their behaviors, poor management, and harassment goes unchecked

Their DEI efforts are often thwarted by old and stubborn faculty who refuse to relinquish any of their unwarranted and underserved power

President is paid and worth a huge amount, but the company still refuses to pay a living wage for their lowest paid employees. 

Surprisingly lax standards during COVID

Ridiculously expensive childcare (20k a year) that most of their employees wouldn't be able to afford

Long working hours and no work-life balance. Consistently messaged in my off time and told to work

job_title: Applications Support Engineer II in Seattle, WA
pros:
Working in the Fred Hutch IT department is full of growth opportunities. Managers encourage learning new technologies and improving processes. If there's a technology that you want to get more experience with, you can probably find someone who knows a lot about it and pick their brain. 

The company also provides ample time off. Fred Hutch observes all US national holidays, and your vacation time grows with each year of employment. 

Hiring from within is also something that is encouraged. Fred Hutch is also very adamant about diversity in hiring whenever possible.
cons: Since Fred Hutch is a non-profit, it's hard for them to stay competitive with the big tech companies in the area.

review_title: Good place to work, although your experience will vary highly by area.
pros:
The Hutch is a place where most of us are tremendously proud to work. Each day, you get to be a part of their mission to advance science and save lives. I'm glad to be here.

In the era of COVID-19 and some troubling times in our nation, Hutch leadership - particularly the Center President and Director - have done an outstanding job of navigating us through it. In that arena, we are all incredibly lucky.

Benefits are pretty good. There's also an on-site child care center, which is expensive (particularly by the standards of non-profit employees) but stellar. Once you obtain full seniority, the paid time off piles up faster than you can use it - definitely a reason I've stuck around.

Some roles are provided with a great deal of autonomy, and that can be a very good thing. It allows room to flex the work around your life needs and work style, and encourages you to manage your growth in your position.
cons:
Advancement is hard to come by, no matter how stellar your performance or how many more duties you've assumed. Some years - like this most recent one - there's no raise for anybody, and that sometimes makes the siren song coming from the for-profit tech and biotech companies come through much louder. I continually have recruiters calling, but haven't sold my soul yet.

Your experiences will vary highly by which lab or program you work in. Most PIs are great, while others have serious management skill deficits. The only major critique of my program is that it's sometimes hard to get answers out of people, and critical information is often not shared in a timely manner, if at all.

pros:
Very good benefits, especially healthcare.

I've seen consistent desire and efforts to embrace diversity/inclusion initiatives, more than I've ever seen in other nonprofits I've worked at. 

Family friendly, on-site childcare (expensive), and feeding/changing rooms in my building.
cons:
Low pay, high turnover. Lack of transparency from management.

There are people genuinely want change -- and are trying -- but we struggle to practice it. Being "too pushy" can make you a target for those who're not ready.

review_title: Fantastic place to work for an institution that has a successful mission to fulfill
pros: Great community feel to all colleagues and staff members. Most are looking out for your advancement and personal goal achievements while still maintaing a high level of professionalism. Beautiful and secure campus located in the heart of downtown South Lake Union amidst waterfront and mountain views.
cons: Parking is terribly crowded and almost impossible to get for a reasonable or reduced rate. Waiting list is extremely long and research staff tend to take priority over administrative staff, no matter the seniority. Senior management is a little disconnected from the rest of the institutition in the sense that they cannot identify with the needs of those support workers who help to run the day to day operations of a research center. There is also not a lot of room for growth above your hiring position that you came in under. This has seemingly been why a lot of people tend to leave the center after a few short years when they come to realize they can no longer further themselves in support roles.

review_title: A Good Place to Work if You're in the Right Department
pros:
For the full-time non-scientific staff, the benefits are very good: medical, dental, sick pay, holidays. 

The mission is good.

Faculty and staff are dedicated and proud to work here.

If you're in the right department, then your work schedule is flexible and co-workers are friendly and it's a great place to work.
cons:
There is HR Employee Relations and IT training that is good, until you've taken every class. 

The pay is at the bottom end of the market scale.

There is no career path for staff. 

Finding the right department can be a challenge. There is a lot of nepotism with many little Emperors working at odds with each other. 

On-the-job training is virtually non-existent. You not only have the learn the system but you have to learn how to work around the system. 

It's very difficult to streamline policies and processes because the old guard doesn't want to be constrained by rules.

There are almost no repercussions for bad behavior or lack of productivity - this goes for faculty and staff.

review_title: The haves, and the have nots
pros: The physical buildings are wonderful, there are two great cafeterias on site, and many of my coworkers have been caring, ethical, intelligent people.  Little pressure to produce, easygoing environment.
cons: "Member track" faculty are treated like gods.  I've been here for a while, so I've seen it all.  Faculty disappear for months with no notice, leaving their employees confused and rudderless.  Faculty treat their employees like slaves, so much so that HR offers a compassionate shoulder to cry on, but no action is EVER taken to deal with borderline sociopathic faculty members.  Your education level is the strongest indicator of how far you can go at FHCRC - if you just have a BS, your career ladder is very short.  Some dedicated people have worked at the same level for 25 years, with no hope of advancement.  It makes me sad to watch.  However, since good work is never rewarded, and bad work is never punished, this is a fairly easy place to work, just floating along collecting paychecks.  The only way to lose your job is to have your grant run out, and that has nothing to do with the quality of your work.  So float on, gaze at the lake, and take a 2-hour coffee break.  No one will notice or care.

review_title: Find a good PI to work for or look else where
pros: The benefits are great and if you have a good PI they will try and take care of you as much as possible. This place will give you all the tools you need to move onto a better paying job and give you a good resume.
cons: The problem here is that there is a HUGE and I mean HUGE disconnect between faculty/senior management and the "workers". They do not care about how little they pay technicians and they give the lowest pay raise they can give. If you plan on making research a career do not try and make one here as a research technician especially in the HVTN it's pointless. They give lame reasons for not paying people properly and also they like to make Research Tech I's do comp time instead of paying them overtime, which I may add is illegal and they are required by law to pay tech I's overtime. They can however do comp time as long as the tech uses it in that same week, rarely happens. Last reason is that their budgets are always too tight, but they can give themselves nice fat pay raises or higher people who are not qualified.

pros: Loved every second of being there!
cons: Patients declining health was always a bummer.

pros: great facilities and communities that encourage communication and collaboration between different departments
cons: Can be a very competitive environment when it comes to receiving grants and publishing papers

review_title: One of the greatest places to work on your career!
pros: This is a terrific place to build a scientific career. The level of scientific achievement and research is world-caliber at this facility. The individual researchers are world experts, publishing in top peer-reviewed journals and trainees from this institute go on to good jobs in research. Access to resources, from journals to facilities for microscopes, specimen processing, data management, etc. is easy and available in-house or you can go elsewhere if you like. There is tremendous support available for career development of trainees, from computer training, to seminars on salary negotiation. In addition, there is Hutch kids for childcare (although I know that there is a waiting list, but that's no different from any other good quality childcare) and great medical benefits, including medical benefits for domestic partners.
cons: Honestly, there aren't really any serious downsides I can think of. At least, not from a research perspective. I can say that if work-life balance is important to you and weighted more towards the 'life' side than the 'work' side (it's fair, everyone gets to decide how they want to live their life), you will not benefit as much from the opportunities here. Obviously, the faculty is pretty serious about their work. That's how they got here. That's hardly a downside if you're trying to advance in your career (and I would count that as a positive, actually).

review_title: Pretty much what all the others say
pros:
*great mission, with projects in Uganda and South Africa. 
*campus: across the street from South Lake Union (the new, clean and safe(er) part of Seattle), each building has roof top decks and break rooms with beautiful views of the water - watch sailboats race and seaplanes take flight/ land.
*nice cafeterias with lunchtime performances by musical ensembles from Cornish College. Bring your own food, as the food is flavorless at best.
*salons and presentations by the scientists doing the research: all inspiring and informative to the non-scientific. 
*transportation benefit seems to be better than other area employers ($15/month for unlimited busses, trolleys/ street cars, ferries, light rail and trains).
*on-site child care, though VERY costly and with VERY limited space
*very diverse population, and very accepting of all: policies and benefits extend to same sex and unmarried couples. It truly is a great feeling to work for such an accepting organization. 
*work-life balance: leave early, take long weekends, whatever you want.
cons:
same as everyone else says:
*ridiculously old-school, total resistance to change
*pay and benefits below industry and area standards.
*unqualified people at all levels, which fosters a very unhealthy hostile environment with no accountability. 
*no career development.

review_title: Time to turn things in the administrative division upside down Gary!
pros: Great mission. Effective research and lifesaving treatments. Wonderful location. Benefits are above average for a nonprofit. Training through HR is fair. Very chill, good work-life balance.
cons: If you are a hard worker, a go-getter that wants to make change - look elsewhere for employment. Complacency and deference to those that have been with Fred Hutch for decades trumps  new, effective ideas. Those that have been in their positions the longest - but might have no real education, work experience or management training - oversee those that are much more qualified. Once these 'managers' realize they are incompetent compared to their direct reports, they try to push them down or even fire them.

pros: Nice campus, nice people, flexibility.
cons: Downtown, paid parking, traffic at Mercer is terrible.

review_title: IT "Leadership" Continues to be a S-Show
pros: Supporting researchers who are trying to save lives. Fantastic staff who are willing to share their knowledge.
cons:
Current CIO is untrusting of anyone other than the friends she hired when she came onboard. The attrition rate (firing, quitting, layoffs) is ridiculously high. The amount of extremely talented, productive, and dedicated people that have left on their own or have been told to leave is insulting and detrimental to the mission of the Hutch. HR doesn't care and clearly the Center's leadership doesn't care. People sometimes just disappear. Little to no communication when staff is let go, even when it's an entire department. You only find out when the person who you've been working with on a major project doesn't show up to meetings or answer their phone. If you're willing to support every horrible idea the CIO has with a smile and lots of enthusiasm, you may last a while. Shame, as the culture used to be one of the best things about working there.
If you're thinking of applying for an IT job in the Admin division, before doing so I would strongly advise you to try and find someone who currently works there, buy them a coffee, and ask lots of questions.

pros: Good work life balance, Team environment is great
cons: Lot of competition, low salaries

pros: There is a great work life balance here and it's very flexible if you have appointments.
cons:
The culture is highly elitist. The scientist/faculty rule this company and there seems to be no rules or boundaries for what they do. They don't have to follow the same guidelines and the team that supports them has to scramble to cover these antics. The faculty and leadership are some of the highest paid I've ever seen across any industry and lots try to fly first class and get it covered.  While they are highly regarded and funded, all of the operational/administrative team that supports them are some of the lowest paid in area and industry. I keep hearing that it's an NPO and people are here for the mission, hence being paid below the industry standard, but when all of the scientist/faculty and leadership are making some of the highest salaries across the country, it hard to swallow the koolaid. 

Lastly, they need some business acumen. This NPO is ran by scientist with no background in leadership or business. If they want to be successful, they need more than scientist without any business background leading their divisions.

pros: I enjoy working with all our wonderful patients.  The treatment technology is world class in treatment.  I feel close to all my co-workers, they feel more like family than co-workers!  My manager empowers me to make a difference with the patients and is supportive of taking your time to focus on their needs and experience.  It makes a world of difference to the patients and for me it is the difference of liking and loving my job.  I can say I really love my job and hope to stay at the SCCA Proton Therapy my entire career!
cons: Medical Insurance companies do not universally cover proton therapy.  This adds stress to patients who this is their best chance at beating cancer.  I feel the proton center does everything they can to help patients but I do wish the pacific northwest had better protections for patients and more regulations on insurance companies to prevent them from denying payment for treatments the patient's physician recommends.

review_title: One of the best non-profits to work for in Seattle
pros: Nothing beats working for an organization that is doing truly world- and- life- changing work.  In the spirit of scientific and creative curiosity, not only is the mission reason enough to the work at the Hutch, but the openness about everything from the science to the administration to the parking situation is extremely refreshing at the Hutch.  The benefits are great, the campus is ideally located and gorgeous, and amenities are impressive - especially for a non-profit.  The pay is comparable to other non-profits in the area and a step above the University of Washington.  The staff are more like family than co-workers.  The famous saying in Seattle is, "everyone wants to work at the Gates Foundation."  However, everyone *should* want to work at the Hutch.
cons: Depending on your field, there is not a lot of room for career advancement.  Some departments are also a bit too quick to hire an outside consultant to do the work that the highly-skilled employees can and should be doing as well, if not better.

review_title: Recent laid off employees treated with lack of empathy and respect.
pros: Good culture diversity. Idea of advancing medicine and science. Long term employees with knowledge. Lots of good mentors willing to give experience to co workers. Advancing science by integrating young adults into the field.
cons: Managers evolved in too much politics. Management lack of communication among departments,   Some department managers evolved in unethical behaviors.  Disrespect to departing employees,  negative talk within departments causing employees to become demoralized.  Low communication between management , HR and payroll.

pros:
- If you're on academic path, a good place to be.
- If you have the backing of leadership, you'll go far.
- I think, given some more time and this new leadership, they may realize that their greatest assets are those scientists not in leadership positions: they are the ones that greatly contribute to the science produced, yet they are rarely acknowledged (let alone celebrated).
cons:
- If you're not on the academic path, yet you're still looking to personally advance science or have a livable wage (in expensive Seattle), this place is NOT for you.
- Only PIs, admin, and grad students are well supported.

review_title: No path for promotions or movement within the company
job_title: Research Technician Supervisor in Seattle, WA
pros: Amazing culture, good benefits, and great people who truly care about what they are doing (no matter how small the job). I have worked at Fred Hutch for almost 10 years and I greatly enjoy working here, you get a feeling that you are making a difference and working toward positive outcomes for many different people and diseases. The campus is very nice and there is a great work-life balance (very family supportive).
cons:
Support staff have no path to move up and be promoted.
There is no easy way to move to a different group, department, or lab. There is little to no support for internal candidates looking to stay at the Hutch but wanting to move to a different position. 
Great talent is lost due to these two issues as excellent performers who want to be challenged end up moving to a different company.

review_title: Great faculty, good opportunities for learning, limited options for advancement.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Seattle, WA
pros: World-class faculty, noble research goals, fantastic location and facilities, friendly environment.  Working here you can feel like you are making a contribution to society by generating knowledge to aid in the understanding of cancer, and potentially work towards programs aimed at improving cancer prevention and treatment.  Generally very supportive PIs that allow for independence of work topics, flexibility of hours, and ongoing education and training.
cons: Very difficult to move up within the organization for junior people or recent graduates.  Can feel like a second-class citizen if you are not tenure-track faculty.  People are generally friendly, but you need to go out of your way to meet people.  Group/lab experience tends to vary widely by PI/division.  Some provide more support than others, especially with non-faculty positions.  Recently the marketing/business aspects of the non-profit have been ramped up, sometimes it seems to the detriment of the science.

review_title: Run away as fast as you can and dont look back. It's a sinking ship.
pros: Good mission and Benefits. But that's it.
cons:
Management doesn't take time to know why so many people are leaving the company, instead they just keep hiring more and more. Incompetent managers are hired. 
People at a high level role come here with big promises as if they'll solve all the problems, but end up milking $$  and spending time on vacation.
People bully each other in the departments. Unhealthy environment, low morale.l Whoever joins Fred hutch starts looking for a different job the 2nd day and spends company time on finding a new job. LOL

If the above explanation doesn't help anyone change their mind about joining this company then don't know what will. 
God bless you if you are a current employee.

review_title: Generally pleasant workplace, very accepting of diversity
pros:
IT department has a fairly healthy internal culture and is the most positive place for women and nonwhite IT staff I've ever worked. The draw of the mission tends to attract compassionate, generous people; the culture within teams tends to be positive and cooperative. 
Large IT department for a nonprofit, reasonably good opportunities for IT professionals looking for a nonprofit career.
Benefits are above average.
cons:
Poor work life balance and flexibility in some IT departments - expect to work a lot of nights and weekends with minimal compensation. Outdated infrastructure is difficult and time consuming to maintain, and causes staff to devote large amounts of time to outdated skillsets. Minimal funding for employee development; without personal initiative in your own free time your skills can fall behind. IT departments are very stuck in their ways and beholden to upper management, enacting substantial change and modernizing the infrastructure is rarely possible.
Parking is expensive, but busing to the Hutch campus is a lot more time consuming than a more to a centrally located office.

review_title: Great mission. Many brilliant and wonderful staff. Growing pains.
pros:
Brilliant scientists at all levels.
Truly compassionate people.
Terrific mission, in both basic and clinical research.
Many on scientific staff are practicing physicians actively treating patients, with great care and concern.
World renowned.
Beautiful campus.
Work flexibility in some positions.
Several of the long-term leaders in the organization are great individuals.
cons:
Culture varies by specific work group or lab (does not in all instances permeate through the organization)
Undergoing rapid change culturally and in staffing.
As a (primarily) grant-funded organization, the organization often operates as a collection of independent laboratories, each with its own drivers and culture. It can be difficult to get everyone to sing the same tune and to feel a part of a cohesive unit with clear organizational objectives.
Communications between individuals and groups can often be highly controlled.

review_title: Fred Hutchinson is a great place to work
pros:
Life-work balance is tremendous.  Schedules are often very flexible especially in the IT sector.  Contribute to the greater good!  When funding ends for one grant there are often opportunities within the Center to move to other grants.  If you work for a Center department that covers multiple grants, your job security is greatly increased.  

The Center often will help grants with staff salaries when funding gaps occur.
cons: Advancement is not quick and there are not stock options.  You may be at the mercy of grant funding which can end leaving grant funded staff looking for work.  A wise employee is always watching for when grants are ending and positioning themselves for the next grant down the pike.

pros: The mission and notoriety of the organization cannot be beat - you feel proud to work at the Hutch. Vacation and sick time are generous, (you will pay out of pocket for medical and dental). The overall atmosphere and people are wonderful - cafes, coffee stands, campus grounds.
cons: Salaries can’t compete with industry standards and cost of living in Seattle.  There are salary limitations for non-scientific staff - you would constantly hear managers and departments reiterate that we're a non-profit, therefore paid less.  Annual "merit" increases are a joke and not evaluated based on performance.  Parking is a nightmare due to construction and location. If your commute only requires one bus, it's doable. Make sure you have a good manager who looks out for the team or you'll never be promoted. I had such high hopes coming into such a recognized organization, but I couldn't last because of the low salary and lack of growth.

review_title: Great for researchers with PhD, but MS analysts are grunts and pay for neither is high
job_title: Statistical Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: Honest and noble mission.  Some legendary statisticians on the staff.  Can have the opportunity to work on some interesting and cutting edge research if you are in the right group.  Good benefits.  Nice facilities.
cons: Nonprofit, so pay is limited.  Quality of the job experience will depend on what division you work for.  Respect for MS level statisticians can be low, and in some groups the tasks assigned could be done by someone with a BS in another field.  There is a ceiling to how high you can climb as an MS, with no further advancement once you hit level V.

pros:
I was part of the opening of the Center and have been continuously proud of working there. Everyone is concerned with giving the best patient care and work hard to do so. 
Patients come for weeks of treatment and it’s possible to really get to know them and impact their disease course. 
Exciting working with some of the best cancer doctors in the world. 
We’ve been able to keep families together by treating kids with brain cancers close to Home. 
Fair wages with regular increases and bonuses for good performers. 
Beautiful environment to work in. 
I’ve worked for many hospitals and this center really is different - very high tech and good employees really make it accessible and understandable for patients. Much more ownership by employees compared to being one department in a big hospital.
cons: Have to be focused on the bottom line to survive ... although every company can say the same thing.

pros: The organizations dedication to eliminating cancer.
cons: Fred Hutch is a wonderful organization that is helping the cancer world tremendously, however I highly suggest staying far away from FH if you are in the administrative field. I had an experience with upper management who harasses, mistreats, disrespects and manipulates the younger employees which caused an extremely toxic work environment. Although others are aware of the behavior, no action takes place to fix the toxicity in the culture at Fred Hutch. It is unfortunate that the Human Resources department is divided into two groups known as “old HR” and “new HR”. No employees within the HR department are on the same page and what is most disappointing, is that policies regarding sexual harassment are interpreted differently across the board. Employees without higher status, such as tenure or a disability, have no chance of being heard, even when they are in the right. The Fred Hutch harassment policy is not an important factor when the person abusing the policy is upper management.  The best decision of my career thus far has been leaving Fred Hutch.

review_title: Groups of great people with great mission...but other groups are anti-social, ackward, and dysfunctional.
pros: Innovative projects, ideas, people (some), and centrally located in Seattle right off freeway on a beautiful campus.
cons: Parking is very expensive.  Childcare is nearly impossible for most workers to afford, and there is a year or more waiting list.  HR is not helpful in any way when a project comes to an end, if you have questions (you may get different answers, depending on who you talk to), and getting hired can be a ridiculously long process.

review_title: Great people & benefits, Decent pay, Some management problems
pros: As the title says, the people are great, as is often the case in not-for-profit. For the most part, everyone wants to be there, which makes a difference to the overall culture and environment. The benefits are great and the pay is on par with for-profits.
cons: Because this is a not-for-profit it does suffer from certain infrastructure/management problems. Depending on your department, you have doctors or nurses doubling as managers. (Management is a skill, and just because you are a bigwig does not mean you have that skill.) Because this is a healthcare industry, they behind the times in certain technological areas (some jobs still use old fax machines, for example). Depending on your job, there may not be room for advancement.

review_title: Good community of individuals passionate about what they do
job_title: Project Coordinator II in Seattle, WA
pros: Large enough to have policies and procedures for most things, but small enough to make it feel personal.  It is easy to get to know most people within your division.  Even at the lowest levels it is easy to get to know upper management of your division, and they are typically willing to work with staff to develop skills and enhance portfolios to keep the job challenging and interesting.  FHCRC is willing to hire those without specific research administration experience if the skills the candidate has are a good match for the position.
cons: Project Coordinators are essentially the single administrative person for their faculty, so they end up doing many tasks outside their job descriptions.  As with all research institutions dependent on outside funding, budgets are tight and there is a Center-wide awareness of costs at every turn.

review_title: Cutting-edge research organization that's making a difference
job_title: Non-research Staff Positions In Various Programs/Labs in Seattle, WA
pros: Great work environment, opportunity to work with talented faculty and staff who are engaged and committed to the mission. Nice facilities, good work-life balance and generous benefits. General reputation for less formality and hierarchy between faculty and staff. Of course, experiences vary across departments, but in general staff are valued and appreciated. Again, varies by group, but in talking with staff at other organizations in the sector, my impression and experience is that there are more advancement opportunities for staff at this organization.
cons: Grant funding can be a challenge for project-based staff, but that's true across the board, not just at the Hutch.

review_title: Nice place to work.  The commute may soon make it not worthwhile.
pros: For a non-profit, it's a good place to work.  Pay is okay, although targeted raises are only about 1% after factoring in cost of living (COLA is not done separately, so it is actually possible to get an effective pay cut here).  Benefits very good.  Nice people, very worthy mission.
cons: The commute has become awful, and promises to get work.  Street work is nearly constant, and with Google's new campus opening soon and the ongoing hiring at Amazon, remaining here may remain untenable for many of us.  A great many employees here are in roles ideal for remote work, even if just a couple times a week.  The Center has been stubborn to embrace this.

pros:
Working for an organization that works to cure cancer and HIV/AIDS
Great location
cons: Lack of skilled management. Project Coordinators (at least mine, I should say) was woefully unskilled in how to manage/supervise, never training you, just expecting you to be psychic when you walk in the door, and setting you up to fail. HR is completely useless. As in other reviews, they do not care about you if you are not science/research staff or faculty. Administrative staff are regarded as second class citizens.

pros: Overall, it is a wonderful place to work.  There are certainly numerous interesting seminars to go to, the research has an important, life-saving, aspect to it and you can do Science all day and night if you want.  The benefits are reasonable given that it is a non-profit organization.  I learned a great deal there about how to do Science, how labs function and, of course, about cancer.
cons: It was difficult to learn anything new in the one lab I worked in because it only performed 6 or 7 different techniques.  When I tried to transfer to another lab to learn new techniques, it did not happen.  My resume may have been limited in techniques.

job_title: Desktop Support Tech II in Seattle, WA
pros: Working with people who have a common goal, and lots of passion for their work. Exciting science happening right under your nose. Management cares about their staff and wants them to succeed; effort to promote from within.
cons: Fred Hutch started as a coming together of several independent research groups, and there is still a lot of separation and some territorial feeling between the groups. I work in IT, where it has been very prevalent in spite of management efforts to move towards a "one IT" structure. Working with hyper-intelligent doctors can be stressful due to massive egos. Pay is on the low side for the IT world, and funding for the whole organization is heavily dependent on federal grants - thus, the sequester is hurting the pay scale considerably. For the same reason, important IT projects are on hold and equipment is aging.

pros: The mission is strong. Feeling like I'm helping people is great. Multidisciplinary institute with many different focuses and specialists so it is an interesting place to work. Seminars are top notch and many interesting speakers come to visit. Strongly leans toward an academic culture.
cons: Day to day can be tough. Sometimes it is difficult to get work done due to negative/toxic environments, slacking off, bad managers, etc. As Fred Hutch is not a slave to profit, it can cause some bloating in the workforce. This part of the culture is tough to deal with. The org is also very flat on the research side. Can be difficult to move up, get raises, or gain new skills. Personal experience will vary depending on your immediate work environment.

review_title: Great work/life balance, Management could improve
pros:
Plushy offices - the offices are much better than some large companies like Amazon or Microsoft. 
Great work-life balance. If you want to come in late and leave early, no one will stop you. Great for people who are active; there's a lot of encouragement to commute by bicycle and general physical fitness, very appropriate for a cancer-prevention org.  The people are generally well-educated and concerned about world issues.
cons: Top management makes all the decisions. I'm in mar-com, and my team and I have to do a lot of education and training on what we do.  While the management has slowly come to learn what is important, they still waste a lot of money on things they do not understand.

pros: People like working here because of the mission, and the quality of the faculty is generally very good to excellent.  The projects are exciting and you can feel like there is a chance what you are doing could really improve life for people with cancer.
cons: Research is a tough business and most of the faculty are working too hard just to keep themselves and their immediate staff going.  Management tries to encourage interdisciplinary activities and support junior faculty but mostly people are left to sink or swim if their personal mentoring committee isn't in a position to help.

review_title: Fred Hutch is a great place to work if you want a fulfilling job, but not a place to make a ton of money
job_title: Research Technician Supervisor in Seattle, WA
pros: The culture of the Hutch is great, the majority of the people who work there are helpful and great to work with. Since so many different diseases and illnesses are researched, not just cancer, you can really be a part of improving many people's lives.
cons: Well to be blunt, unless you are a PI, you should work at Fred Hutch because you want to make a difference, not because you want to make a lot of money. Since the PI's are "managers" and are not trained in how to manage, it can be difficult to move up or get good raises.

review_title: It's a great cause to fight for, but the effort doesn't pay
job_title: Research Technician II in Seattle, WA
pros: Great sick leave policy. Ok vacation policy. Amazing retirement benefits. Flexible work environment. Nice people to work with (depending on your group).
cons: Each group is essentially run like their own entity, responsible for their own budgets and salaries. There's very little space to move up in responsibility (and especially pay) if you stay in the same position for the long term. There's very little cross training available to staff if they want to say move to another specialty or even add to their resume.

job_title: Research Technician I in Seattle, WA
pros:
Flexible hours
Good benefits
Bike riding subsidy
Good affordable food
Rooftop access with grill
Free beer on Fridays
Great community of scientists and staff
cons:
Depending on what lab you work in, or building, the atmosphere can feel kindof stiff. People rarely acknowledge one another in the halls or get together for lunch, it seems. Though this might be a part of the "freeze" in Seattle culture that I've heard about.
Parts of the employee website are severely outdated and non intuitive.

job_title: Lead Cancer Information Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Fred Hutch offers fantastic benefits and a collaborative work environment that is facilitated by strong management.  This fast-paced institution is an exciting place to work as there are always discoveries being made, and there is so much to learn by being a member of any team.  There are also opportunities to work within various different departments.
cons: It is difficult to live in Seattle on a non-profit salary, although they do pretty well for a non-profit in terms of benefits.  In some departments, opportunities for career growth are limited and difficult.  Fred Hutch is also a very competitive place to get into, so initially finding a job and/or moving into a different position can take a long time.

pros: Get to work with very accomplished scientists, leads to PhD programs if that is your interest. Plenty of networking opportunities, a fun place to work depending on your lab.
cons: Some PIs take advantage of your salary status (true in science in general, I know). Routinely working 60-80 hours/wk which ends up being less than minimum wage in Seattle. You have to LOVE the work. Some PIs are very malignant, get honest advice from current lab members before signing up for a two year commitment.

review_title: Non-profit not equal to nice people
pros: The pay is somewhat competative for a non-profit, has a good reputation in the science community so it will look good on your resume.
cons: Some very angry people and some toxic environments depending on where you are located within.  There "favorites" games is played somewhat, you really have to be on board, attend all social type functions or you are look down on.

review_title: Strong organization but big growing pains
pros:
Easy to see the direct impact your job makes to the accomplishments of the organization (even if you aren't in science). 
Healthy work/life balance. 
New senior leadership is steering the organization to become an even stronger world-renowned research center.
Opportunities to learn about a wide variety of research projects and accomplishment.
cons:
Rapid growth is held back by tenured mid-level management hesitant to change the way things have always been done. The unnecessarily challenging growing pains of some key groups are losing valuable employees. 
Significant turnover within administrative functions created an unstable environment.

pros: The institution has a desire to improve, you have the ability to make some changes which is nice. Beautiful campus, decent benefits. More functional than other academic medical centers I have worked for.
cons:
The rest of the consortium is kind of a mess. However, your job may be removed enough from all of that so that you don't notice it.
Politics, politics.
Can't work from home.

review_title: Sliding downhill; needs to strive for better times.
pros:
Acceptable salary and benefits, particularly for non-profit, and, with the right supervisor, it is very possible to achieve a good work-life balance here.  Very friendly work community, with a diverse set of talent, both scientific and technical.  The Center still conducts world-class research.

Despite taking my star rating down a peg from a couple years ago, I still would recommend the Center to job-seekers.  Although the list of "Cons" below is quite lengthy relative to the "Pros," hardly any of them apply to me or my position in particular.  I enjoy my position, and the Center too, for the most part, but am aware that my situation may in some instances be the exception.
cons:
These have more to do with how the Center is managed as a whole, rather than day-to-day work experiences, with a couple of exceptions.

Annual raises aren't what they used to be.  When they are provided (usually less than 3%/year), they are often lost to increases in insurance premiums, cost hikes in the cafeteria (more on that later), and other employee-borne costs.  

Given the current funding crisis (due to NIH cuts and sequestration), the Center is perpetually on the brink of money starvation.  During these times, Center leadership will often make some foolhardy fiscal choices, such as building a flashy skybridge across Eastlake while simultaneously conducting layoffs or cutting funding to vital research programs.  The Center has stepped-up its fundraising efforts and, much to my chagrin, has undertaken the practice of continually pestering its own employees to donate through payroll deduction; this practice has left a very bad taste in the mouths of many here, including some at senior levels.  In a way, may of us already donate the opportunity cost of a better compensation package elsewhere to the Center's noble research causes.

The Center in recent years has also "off-shored" many campus services and amenities. Most notably, food service has been contracted out to an overpriced, out-of-town outfit.  Lunch used to cost $5, now it's closer to $10 for less quality, smaller portions, and bad attitudes (undoubtedly the fault of inept food services management).  Many of the employees are ex-Hutch food services staff, who I feel were ripped off in this transaction.  The cafes are a sad place.

Finally, and very importantly, your mileage at the Center will vary greatly depending on your principal investigator.  The Center is a community of much smaller research groups.  Most of the scientists here are great, but a handful verge on sociopathy.  Be sure to ask very pointed questions during your interview, and try to "feel out" other members of the staff to see whether they're happy.  Scientists here have carte blanche (HR policy, nor labor laws, nor sometimes even hard reality, can touch them), and can practically get away with anything, and Center human resources is entirely useless when it comes to resolving workplace issues, so it is of crucial importance to figure out whether a particular position is a good match.

Final note, the Center often advertises positions that are actually based at the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance (SCCA), its clinical partner.  Do yourself a favor and steer a wide path around that place.

pros:
Fascinating research.  Great seminars!
Almost all members are great to work with, nice offices, nice location close to downtown.  
Easy shuttle to UW or SLU.  

Matching 401K, good health benefits.

May be a pro or con, but tends to shut down after 5:30pm or on weekends.
cons:
Food options can be limited and not subsidized.  There aren't really cafes or restaurants nearby.    

The coffee is costly and absolutely the worst unless you make it yourself.   
Noone is going to make you free food, take your dry cleaning.   

I personally think salaries are low for software types who can make much more in the private sector.

I don't like to think about the animal labs.

review_title: Bone Marrow Transplant Advanced Practice Provider
pros:
- RNs are experienced
- Amazingly supportive work environment, fellow APPs and attending physicians always available for questions or opinions. 
- Supportive management with constant systems-improvement projects
- Up-to-date knowledge, treatments, and clinical trials
- Lots of clinical resources
- 2 months of paid vacation a year, plus benefits
- Ability to expand into immunotherapy or pick up shifts in general heme-onc
- Months-long rotations between inpatient and outpatient shifts 
- Opportunity to gain privileging in marrow harvest first-assist, bone marrow aspiration/biopsy, lumbar punctures, moderate sedation
- Ongoing education is easily available with weekly lectures and meetings
cons:
- Pay is low-average
- Work-life balance is sometimes difficult (improving with newer staffing model)
- Months-long rotations between inpatient and outpatient shifts (can be a pro or con depending on your work style)

pros: Opportunity to contribute to meaningful mission statement. Responsible employees have freedom within the scope of their jobs to provide creative solutions to department/organization challenges. I frequently come in contact with general folks and those in my personal life who have been treated or had a loved one treated for cancer here and have nothing but respect and admiration for the place and staff who treated them on their journey. That is the best thing about working here - a place that makes a positive impact on so many lives.
cons: External factors over which we have no control (such as sequestration) that nevertheless impact us.

review_title: Decent place to work with some issues
job_title: Statistical Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits and relaxed atmosphere.  People are usually nice and more than happy work with you or provide a consult.
cons: Pay is lower then if you worked in industry.  Very isolated work environment (if you require interaction and collaboration this is not the place to work).  Unless you have a PhD career advancement is very limited.  If you live outside of the city the commute is pretty brutal.

review_title: Great for scientists and lab workers. Disappointing for all other.
pros:
Every review has valid points and you'll notice a pattern that folks who work directly with science give good review in general and all others are dissatisfied. So if you are a scientist or a lab support person, do whatever you can to work at this prestigious institution. Admin, IT, marketing, etc.? Better look else where. I write this as a person with over 5 years of experience working in a non-scientific role.

PROS:
1) Prestige of working for a world class research institution.
2) New-ish buildings and wonderful location.
3) Generous retirement benefit.
cons:
1) Low pay.
2) Palace intrigue.
3) Inconsistent IT resource and support.
4) Funding challenges (which means job security).
5) Lack of advancement.

review_title: Good place to learn new skills
pros: The Hutch participates in some amazing research. It feels really good to be able to play a small part in the research happening at the Hutch, and people feel very passionate and dedicated to this work. Work life balance is promoted, and there is a general understanding that you have a life outside of work. A lot of internal courses to develop "soft skills", and the Coop offers a lot of great courses as well.
cons:
There are several reasons why I left the Hutch:

1. Complete lack of transparency and no value placed on their employees or their careers. There is one performance review performed annually, that does not lead to any sort of opportunities for advancement. Feedback given is vague, and managers don't care about the careers of their employees. No feedback is elicited from coworkers, and those who make the most noise/cause the most drama get all of the attention. A lot of false promises are made and never delivered on.

2. Similar to reason 1, there is no chance for career advancement or effort placed in developing employee's careers. I was able to learn a lot while at the Hutch, but those opportunities were all things I sought out on my own, and paid for myself. They say each employee receives money for professional development each year, but I did not find that to be true. When I found opportunities I was interested in I was told that there was not money to pay for it (around $500), and I ended up paying out of pocket.

3. Cold  and political culture. While generally people are very nice, a few bad eggs ruin the culture. People are generally reserved and keep to themselves. Some have very strong opinions and are very disrespectful. If you don't play the political game, you will not be recognized here and will remain invisible.

In general, I did appreciate the type of projects I worked on and the skills I obtained working here. This is a good place to work and develop some skills, and then move on. There is no opportunity for career advancement here, nor do they care about your career.

job_title: Statistical Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: It has very interesting research. Also, there are many teams here, so you can switch from one group to another.
cons: It's non-profit, so you can't expect great pay, and burnouts.... And the location is not great, with pretty bad traffic nearby. There are some buses that come here, but it's still in this awkward, not quite downtown, but traffic is just as bad location.

pros:
Good benefits
My department does not enforce a dress code and I can adjust my schedule however I see fit
Good mix of age, gender, and race diversity 
Pays well
Beautiful campus
Cafeteria food is super good
cons:
Company culture isn't really there. I feel like FH is really divided by what lab/department you work in. 

Policies and rules vary by department, and I don't think Fred Hutch HR is doing much to regulate them. My specific department manager was unable to provide me with written policies regarding sick leave, vacation, etc. Because nothing was written down and signed, my manager was able to make up new policies on the spot and without review.

review_title: Great organization, limited opportunity for growth
job_title: Software Development Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: Overall, the Hutch is a fantastic place to work.  Incredible benefits, e.g. onsite clinic with PT and doctor and 7% 401K match.  Awesome, smart folks doing great science makes it feel like a real community and provides a strong sense of fulfillment.
cons: The structure of academic research is such that each lab operates as its own small business, which means limited opportunities for growth.  Especially for non-PhDs, there are not many avenues to move up in seniority or responsibility.

review_title: Wonderful, challenging, stressful (constant grant writing), fabulous people to work with
job_title: Senior Staff Scientist in Seattle, WA
pros:
One of the best research institutes I have worked in
Wonderful people
Lots of flexibility (emphasis is on getting the work done, rather than time-card punching)
Wonderful mentors
Good benefits 
Exposure to great ideas & lots of encouragement to collaborate
Support /infrastructure (eg HR IT etc) very good
Lovely campus
cons:
pay typical of non profit, so not great, but OK 
stressful vis-a-vis having to constantly scrabble for funds to cover salary - endless grant writing as all salaries are paid from grant income: there are  thus no contracts. And in the current climate it's getting harder and harder to do this successfully.  (but this is endemic in research in any case).

pros: Freedom to do your best science. Great support from leadership. Financial support for your pilot research. First class admin and support staff. Beautiful facilities set on the shores of Lake Union. Dedication to the mission of the best science in the service of reducing the societal burden of cancer. Opportunities to be promoted from within. My entire career has been here and it's all been worthwhile.
cons: Pay is better than most universities but less than most cancer centers. No sense of community across research groups. Every PI runs their own show so the quality of the experience for support staff depends on the research group.

review_title: Collaborative, purposeful and thriving research community
pros: One of the top two cancer research centers on the West coast, this non-profit research institution is integrated with the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance, which receives patients from around the Pacific Northwest and colleborates closely with the University of Washington and Seattle Children's Hospital.  Even the architecture is designed to promote collaboration.  Research includes basic, immunology (esp. graft vs. host), clinical, infectious disease (VIDI), epidemiology and public health.  On-site seminars give it a true learning environment feel, as do seminars on bioinformatics and management for employees.
cons: Not really specific to this institution, but government cuts to funding have really made it more difficult to thrive in a primarily academic institution.

review_title: I felt that in a small way that I was making a difference to the current and future health of others.
job_title: Data Coordinator II in Seattle, WA
pros: Great people to work with and for.  Great team work toward a common goal.  I felt appreciated.  I liked working for a well respected reseach organization that made a difference to the health of others.  Generous benefit package.
cons: Some jobs combine many responsibilities and ask for higher skills without proper compensation for the position.  I understand because of study budgets, but it's still not right.

review_title: The Hutch is a good place to work, but not a good place to develop your career.
pros:
You're work will help make people healthier and happier.
Work-life balance is respected.
Personal health is supported.
Benefits are decent.
Family friendly.
Accepting of all different kinds of people.
cons:
People in management are successful MDs and PhDs and often have neither the training nor talent for managing people.
People without MDs or PhDs are undervalued.
Very little opportunity for moving up, getting meaningful raises, etc., unless you move to a different group within the Hutch.
IT infrastructure is embarrassingly behind.
Pay is low.

pros:
This review is for the Statistical Center for HIV and AIDS Research and Prevention (SCHARP), which is a organization within Fred Hutch.

- Brilliant staff, faculty, and investigators. You'll work with some investigators and faculty who are literally among the best in the world in their field. 

- Great atmosphere. People are generally friendly, supportive, and professional. 

-  You'll have the opportunity to work on some really neat studies and projects. 

- The Fred Hutch campus is really pretty with a lot of areas to take a break inside and outside.

- Flexible work schedules with the possibility to work from home a day or two a week. 

- Great health insurance and sick leave allowance.

- Lower level managers are generally supportive and respond well to new ideas. 

- The organization is making a genuine effort to streamline inefficient processes. 

- You are allowed to work mostly independently. 

- Excellent work-life balance. Rare that you have to work more than 40 hours a week.
cons:
- The cafeteria food is very healthy but also not very good. It's also overpriced. 

- No on campus gym or recreational areas.

- Some projects are mind numbingly boring, and there are a lot of processes that are currently delegated to statisticians hat should be delegated to nonstatisticians. 

- The pay is what you would expect for a non-profit. 

- Initial vacation time is only 2 weeks. This is not competitive with the private sector for which 3 weeks is fairly standard.
 
- Vertical advancement is limited.

- The organizations efforts to implement new regulatory standards has created more bureaucracy, making it harder for people to do their jobs.

review_title: Bloated Ineffective Administration and Good Ole Boys Club
job_title: Department Administration Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
You don't actually have to work while your at work-very little oversight.
Supportive environment for balding men.
Everybody is a 'Director'.
Great life-work balance.
cons: There is no supervisor or manager development or 360 review process: ineffective supervisors have no reason to better themselves or their team.  The HR department, while nice, has no power to influence this issue when there are behavioral issues.   Administrative pay increases are cost of living.

pros: Front row seat to important and inspirational work. The campus is beautiful, fun and feels like a community. Access to amazing speakers and education happening on the campus. Interesting work. Lots of opportunities to move into different roles once you're in the Fred Hutch system.
cons: Fred Hutch does not value non-scientific staff the way it should. The scientists are the rock stars, as they should be, however, administrators and other non-scientific staff make things happen and pave the way for the science to happen through fundraising, PR, operations management, and much more.

pros: Higher level of learning and understanding about the organization and its departments and divisions, meeting people from all over the world and developing a rapport, more intimate understanding of specific expertise; good benefits, great location, passionate people.
cons: Position can be as much of a personal assistant as it is an executive assistant, significant amount of hand holding, career growth can be stunted unless leaping to a different career path, non-science people are not treated as well/kindly as those with a science degree

pros: Flexible work schedule, worthy company goal.  Depending on the department can be great.
cons: With a high amount of NIH funding, Fred Hutch is subject to the high and lows of federal funding sources. There are no repercussions for bad work ethic/behavior, a lot of tribal knowledge, very little training or department orientation (again, depending on the department). Limited professional growth for administrative roles.

review_title: Great mission, great place to work
pros: The Hutch is a very collaborative environment. Research encompasses a broad array of areas in the biomedical sciences. On site child care that is very well-regarded. Good benefits.
cons: Experience can be highly variable depending on which group or lab you join. Depending on what kind of environment you work best in, you may have to do a little digging to learn about the culture of the particular group/team/lab you are joining.

pros: Great benefits, mission, and physical work environment (mostly). What training classes they have are usually very good. Casual atmosphere.
cons: Most groups within the Center are independently grant funded and managed, If your group's grants run out, your group shuts down and your job is lost. It is not like a hospital that has a single, unified management and budget and can move staff around as needs change. Many groups are run by scientists with little business savvy or leadership skills.

review_title: Nice company to work for. However interview your manager carefully.
job_title: Systems Analyst/Programmer V in Seattle, WA
pros: Awesome benefits package. Great atmosphere and great people to work with. There is a lot of talented people. The company is doing great things toward cancer research and treatment.
cons: Be careful of who you work for there. Most people are great to work with but some have been promoted when they really didn't have what it takes to be in management.

pros: The commitment the company has to it’s patients and employees makes it an incredibly rewarding place to work.  My co-workers feel like family, which makes the time I spend at work much more enjoyable than other places I’ve been employed. Each week at patient graduation I hear the difference the treatment and the employees have made to the lives of our patients and their family, and it makes me so proud to be part of such important work.
cons: It's a new company so it's still working on defining it's procedures and processes.

review_title: A good place to work for most.
pros:
- Great pay relative to other non-profits.
- Decent benefits; good leave if you've been around awhile.
- Relaxed, flexible working environment.  Nice offices.  Friendly colleagues.
- Good, but expensive, onsite cafeteria and child care.  I suggest bringing your lunch, as the cost of food is out of line with most non-profit salaries.
cons:
- You work in a government-sponsored non-profit, so pay is not as good as you might find in industry.  Also, job security can be an issue.  
- Scientific staff and non-scientific staff are treated as two different castes.  If you have a Ph.D. behind your name, you get much better benefits and carte blanche do do as you please.  This can hurt morale in some corners of The Hutch.
- "Your mileage may vary."  I am lucky to work under some pretty level-headed PIs and managers.  However, there are many horror stories to be had from elsewhere in The Hutch.  Ask pointed questions during your interview; "buyer beware!"  If you get a lousy PI, don't expect HR to bail you out; Employee Relations (a division of HR) is completely useless, and is only there to serve the scientific staff, not you.
- SCCA (clinical arm of FHCRC).  Stay away from there.  It is culturally very different from the Hutch, despite the fact that they try to co-brand the two organizations.

These negatives take more space than the positives, but are meant to warn you of what can happen at The Hutch; more likely than not, these things won't happen to you - at least not all of them.

pros: Relaxed work environment, location, pretty good benefits package.
cons:
Fred Hutch is not a bad place to work. Because it is non-profit, there's no incentive to work hard or sharehodlers to answer to so the pace can be relaxed. As a matter of fact, some people seem to be not doing anything productive; I have been here for a few years and I can count a handful of people where honest to goodness I do not know what they do all day. Because it's relaxed and pretty cushy, complacency is common and people don't want to leave. Turnover here is below average therefore career advancement is limited. If you are a person with ambition, look elsewhere or stay for a couple of year for experience /title on your resume and pack your bags for career growth at another organization. 

Due to low turnover rate and lack of shareholders to answer to, you have warring factions battling each other for power and control. I see this happening at all departments in the organization; from scientific divisions to IT, alliances are formed and traps are set up to cause failure or embarrass your adversary. I have worked in both the government and private sectors and this place is one of the worst for politics. 

If you thrive on politics, this will be a good place for you. I do have to warn you though, it is a contact sport here not for the faint of heart. Don't get me wrong, Fred Hutch do have good people working there but like any other organizations, it's all about your department and manager. Come work here if you want to be part of a noble mission but don't be so naive in thinking that because it's non-profit, all the corporate BS doesn't exist and everyone's working as a team for the greater good. I joined the organization with that kind of ideology which was quickly crushed. I suspect there's some sort of self-selection going on here. People with ambition and dislike politics leave, complacent people and political masters stay. 

To succeed here, first join a good alliance, don't make too much waves, do the minimum necessary and all will be ok. As for me? I'm at the tail end of my carrer so the relaxed pace is perfect for me. I'm happy to just go through the motion with a steady paycheck and medical/dental insurance. If you were my children, I'd tell you to consider elsewhere first and only work here as a last resort.

review_title: Good job for a few y
pros: Good casual working environment, benefits are good, pay is decent, and people are friendly.
cons: No real opportunity for job growth or promotion.  HR department seems to lack any real substance.  Very little sense or promotion of a community within the overall organization, only small cliquish-type groups.  In essence, the politics underlying the work environment drive this ship--which is unfortunate.

job_title: Project Manager II in Seattle, WA
pros: Beautiful campus and close to the water.
cons: The reviews on here are planted by HR and upper management.  This place will chew you up and spit you out.  Managers are awful and the doctors save all bedside manner for their patients.  Do not work here, the pay is below scale and the amount of work you do is often many jobs rolled into one.  I've heard stories from VIDD division that would make you cringe.  CRD is no better.   Sure they give you 140 hours of "free" sick leave but make you feel so guilty for using it you end up working sick and never getting better.

pros:
The organization's mission makes it easy to stay motivated and engaged

Good work/life balance

Excellent benefits
cons:
Salaries not competitive 

Many employees have their own offices, which does not seem like the most efficient use of multi-million dollar buildings by a not-for-profit

review_title: Amazing mission and purpose however culture is shifting to be more corporate
pros: You get to be a part of curing cancer, there isn't a much better feeling than that!  Benefits are good, onsite employee health clinic is free and easy to access.
cons: Vacation time is lacking, only receive 12 days upon hire, many companies are giving 3+ weeks and the traffic is getting even worse.

review_title: Innovative and exciting place to work
job_title: Research Technician III in Seattle, WA
pros: Science is the most important thing that is focused on at Fred Hutch which is a nice difference between corporate world and non profit.  It was a very welcoming and friendly place.
cons: There is not as much collaboration between groups as there should be which in the end could aid in scientific advancement quicker.  Unfortunately there is not enough money spent on paying their technicians enough money to be competitive with the biotech world so they lose a lot of good people.

pros: The Hutch is great place to grow in a research career. The environment/culture is full of really smart and excited people around constantly.
cons: Sometimes the researchers are out of touch with patient's needs because they are so pressured to put out research publications. This can put a lot of pressure on coordinators as well, without much recognition for the work they also put in.

pros: The mission is wonderful.  A lot of nice people.
cons: IT Services Management feels immature and unstable at times, searching for their identity and still finding their legs.   In this setting, one or two bad managers can do a lot of damage.  Currently, an outbreak of bad management is hurting morale and causing discontent.  Until this situation stabilizes, job seekers are advised to look elsewhere.

review_title: Very incredible work but poor training, high stress environment
job_title: Research Technician I in Seattle, WA
pros: Fred Hutch is a great place to work if you are interested in pursuing an MD or PhD down the line (or if you already have these degrees).  The research here is top of the line, and many of the labs are very organized.  It's a collaborative place to work.
cons: It being the high quality research center it is means that people are under a lot of pressure to perform to the best of their abilities.  In my case, I did not receive adequate training to be proficient as quickly as possible.

review_title: good place to work for lazy people
pros:
The Hutch was established on the work of some stellar scientists and there are still some excellent programs and staff making important advances in the study of cancer, HIV and now with the new head honcho, there will be more focus on infectious diseases (they bought him a new building). So, good cache to say you work at the Hutch.
Benefits are good with plenty of personal, sick and vacation days, 401K matching, etc.
Transportation benefit is excellent - $15 a month gives you a Puget Sound pass that allows you to take any ferry, any commuter bus or train, etc.
cons:
The HR folks who curate the job postings and hiring process are hideous. Don't expect them to ever answer their phones or return an email, even after multiple contacts. I don't know who they're there for, but it's not for you, even if you work there.
As another poster mentioned, the PhDs/PIs are like gods and can do no wrong and are all part of the "ain't we great" club. They also know nothing about administration. Money and materiel are wasted like crazy and efficiency is of no interest to anyone who knows they've got a paycheck coming until the grant runs out in 201x.. A lot of dead wood folks who do little or nothing. A "feel good" yearly performance review process that does not identify sub-par performance leading to improvement or dismissal. As the title said, this is a good place for lazy folks who don't have a personal drive for excellence.

review_title: IT Dept. hypocrisy and management incompetence.
pros: I love my coworkers. Some are just coasting for a paycheck but most IT workers, except management, are smart and hard working. It has been awesome to work with them. Work is very flexible and telecommuting is allowed as long as you get your work done on time. The Hutch IT department is constantly learning and deploying new technology and gears so learning opportunity is there.
cons:
Although the department says they promote from within, it is definitely not the case. A couple of my coworkers applied for an entry level management job and lost to another outside candidate that used to work at the boss' old company. It's peculiar that almost all the new management hires used to work with the boss. 

My coworker and I have been working at the Hutch for 10+ years with glowing reviews each year, not that it automatically qualifies us for the job but we definitely don't feel we are any less qualified than the person hired; we have been told by several people the same thing as well. What's more hurtful was the reason they told us why we didn't get the job, which was complete bullsh**. We are all adults, just tell us the real reason please. I just wish I didn't waste my time going through the vigorous interviewing process which consists of 3 interviews and probably 6+ hours of my time. 

The morale is really low right now with critical systems breaking often and blatant cronyism in hiring practice.  Scientists are fuming and screaming at us for the bad and broken services we provide. I feel embarrassed to work at IT right now, we are not helping the Hutch's mission by helping the scientists do their jobs. Heck, with systems breaking left and right, we are impeding their research.  We are hiring more supervisors and managers, not worker.
