It's getting to be a big bloated corporation like where the boss came from.

pros: Great mission and science with new discoveries coming out almost daily.  Nice campus and location.
cons: Principal Investigators have complete control over the place and everything must be run through them and by committee.  Nearly impossible to influence positive change with respect to administrative functions, people, recruiting, and programs.  Not progressive in any way and full of silos and clicks.

review_title: Being in the lab at Fred Hutch
pros: Very  organized administration and an interesting and stimulating environment with coworkers from all over the world.  It is a very nice place to work.
cons: The pay if on the lower side.  There are not many opportunities to move up in the lab environment.  I think this is a good 3-5 year job for a young person just leaving school.

review_title: Rewarding work, great patients, great friends...
pros: Working for this center has been one of the best experiences I've ever had.  The Doctors are amazing and my co-workers are  people I like spending time with both at work and off work.
cons: Sometimes I miss the resources of a larger hospital but feel like individuals have more impact here then in larger hospital systems.   We use multiple computer systems which can be clucky.

pros: Nice facilities, including buildings, cafeterias, and library. Home to many experts in cancer research and epidemiology. Excellent seminar series.
cons: Leadership does not truly care about junior researchers' development. Few opportunities for advancement to faculty level. Competitive environment; you are basically on your own. Institution grows by recruiting from outside, rather than developing its own talent. There is a lot of institutional politics--you need a bigshot patron to advance. Inadequate connections = sputtering career. A good place to train for a while, then leave.

pros:
You are able to have a career in medical research here, does it get much better than that? My direct supervisor was really good, he was very thoughtful about how he communicated to employees. He would often ask for our opinions regarding management decisions. It made it so we were all very invested in the research.

Excellent benefits including medical, dental, subsidized bus passes, healthy challenges (where you compete to make healthy lifestyle changes) with benefits like free or reduced fitbits, and a locker room (for those commuting by bike). Overall a lot of people that are really passionate about their work. Everyone working 20 hours or more gets full benefits. The HR department was more helpful than most companies. They really help you find the best people when hiring and help with conflict resolution if asked.
cons: Parking is expensive for employees. Also, most people are funded on NIH grants which means every few years there can be a big transition in funding within individual studies which can lead to layoffs. The "center funded" (non-grant funded) people have gone through quite a few layoffs themselves since overall funding decreased with the recession. In short, working there during the recession produced many of the same, scary outcomes that everyone in the USA was facing. I think the HR department is really good about trying to keep good people at the Hutch and have helped several of my former employees find work with other studies after we went through a major transition.

review_title: Good people & benefits, but poor management
pros: Great benefits, including quickly-accruing vacation time, and vacation days roll over! Generally wonderful people to work with.
cons:
Many non-managers have been appointed as managers. These are professional nurses, for example, who don't know HOW to be a manager, and therefore simply don't manage. It causes a great deal of stress for employees who are used to well-managed environments. 

Not a lot of room for growth in your career, but that might be expected from a health-care facility like this one.

pros: Fred Hutch has a good benefits system in place and is a great place to start if you want to get experience for med school or a PhD program.
cons:
Fred Hutchinson does not value it's Technicians, while it provides good benefits, it provides little to no salary increases and a very low starting pay.  Principal Investigators are treated like gods, and can literally do no wrong.  PIs are very smart in science, but have no training or understanding of their employees or of what their employees make.  It is entirely up to the PI if a technician is published: some PI's are great, if you put in a large amount of work for the paper, your name will get on it.  However many PIs refuse to put anyone on a paper unless they have  PhD by their name, even if the person has worked on the entire project and assisted with writing the paper.  If you have an issue with a PI you have no recourse but to quit. 
Also, it is an unwritten law, which your lab manager will tell you after you've been hired, that you are expected to work overtime, but not get paid for it.
Also, due to the PI's ignorance of their finances I have had 2 different PI's offer Tech II positions, only to rescind it once the offer was accepted.  One realized he didn't have the money to pay the higher salary, the other decided he wasn't sure he wanted to offer the tech II title.

pros: Great cause, cutting edge science, socially responsible to environment, surrounding community and employees by encouraging carpooling, biking to work, flexible hours, recycling/composting, organic menus, onsite childcare (although difficult to get in).  Was one of the first employers in WA State to provide nursing rooms.
cons: Difficult to find parking if you are an off-site employee and need to go to main campus for meetings.  Largely funded by grants and private donations so is highly affected by fluctuations in economy.

pros: Great facilities, exceptional scientists, nice location, and highly motivated coworkers.  On-site (but hard to get) daycare too.
cons: Demanding and high pressure atmosphere, low pay (for training positions) and general lack of appreciation for the "training" scientists doing all of the work.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Seattle, WA
pros: Speaking as a post-doc, the Hutch has a fantastic support system. Even though its a non-profit and not directly affiliated with an academic institution, they do a lot to support graduate and postdoctoral researchers and career development. Excellent facilities, strong IT support staff and fantastic library resources won't leave you waiting or in the dark for long. Even their cafeteria is great! Also (added bonus), post-docs get retirement benefits!
cons: Every lab is its own microculture -  but that's not a comment about the Hutch, as much academic science.

review_title: Lot's of smart people with a mission, but can be a black hole ....
pros: There are a lot of smart people here, with very benevolent mission (cure cancer).  This is a very academic institution (each lab is it's own entity), with the business/ shared IT resources being more like a traditional business.  The academic flavor brings a fair amount of flexibility in terms of your work schedule/ arrangements (dependent on which PI you work for), and the benefits are great!
cons:
Because the institution is fairly academic, you can feel a little siloed from others (although that is changing with "The Coop" being a newly created entity to try to bring data scientists/ analysts from across the organization together).

Career Progression/ continuing education is pretty much something you have to figure out yourself (there is no clear guidance in this regard, unless you are in a tenure-track lab-PI position), and it is easy to end up "stuck" in the same position for decades even (your PI may never bring up conversations about what your 1 to 5-year plan/goals are).  They have recently implemented scholarships for individuals to go to summer schools, etc, but this is something you have to compete to receive (as opposed to a guaranteed funding commitment to your career progression).  Granted, this is a non-profit, so it is understandable that money can be tight.

The above observations are not criticisms of the Hutch, per se, but of academic/ research institutions in general.  Also, this is spoken from someone who was attached to a lab (on the academic side of things), so if you're a part of Center IT or HDC (or other "business-like" groups, you may have a different experience).

job_title: Research Technician II in Seattle, WA
pros:
Very interesting science

Several excellent seminar series

Exposure to cutting edge research

Some nice employee events

Good experience with cutting edge techniques
cons:
Disclaimer- Every lab is run independently so the PI's management style is different from lab to lab

The lab I have been working in is a large lab (30-40 people) with a lot of projects going. Each post doc (5-6 post docs) works with their technicians pretty independently from the rest of the lab. This set up seems more similar to how an industry lab is structured to me. Also, it seems a very different structure from most other labs. 

That being said, there has been a large amount of turnover since I have been with the lab (almost a dozen people in a little over a year). The reasons why I will be leaving as well are:

Centre wide compensation policy not being followed by the PI (no pay increases unless you threaten to leave for industry)

No career development for technicians (you will not be promoted)

Very intense days and long hours (pretty regular 50 hour weeks)

Poor seating (putting people's "desks" in pretty unfortunate places)

In general, the only reason to work at the Hutch as a technician is if you plan on getting experience before going into a PhD program, or if your significant other has a high paying career. Indeed, the lab is split in half by those two categories. The only technicians that have stayed much beyond 2 years have partners that work in tech and can support them with the very poor pay from the Center. You are largely wasting your time working here instead of industry if that is your ultimate goal.

review_title: Being a part of the cure.
pros: Some of the most innovative research leading to improved health care is being done at the Hutch.  Working in this type of environment and being a part of this progress, even in a non-scientific capacity, is fulfilling.  As far as the work environment goes, there is a renewed focus on process and standards of work (administrative-oriented) that will in the long run further help the scientific advancements.
cons: Sometimes the cultural contrast of academic vs the new push towards more corporate underpinnings can be uncomfortable in the transition. It will get better.

pros: Shared resources (core labs, library, bioinformatics, etc.) are all staffed by helpful, knowledgeable people. Dozens of interesting talks each week. People are genuinely motivated by the mission to fight cancer. Research lab culture varies widely; do your homework, ask for opinions (people are usually frank), ask to sit in on a meeting, and you'll find a good fit.
cons: It's a large institution, so transitioning out under-performers takes a long time. Politics can make it difficult to move laterally.

pros: Fred Hutch has a good mission and upper level leadership. Benefits are decent. People are generally happy to work here.
cons: Silos between departments. Fred Hutch has vacation/sick time vs. PTO so not as much vacation as competitors. Administrative positions pay less than competitors. Too many consultants that waste time and money.

review_title: It's been a great place to gain experience and a very stable job during this economic time.
job_title: Research Technician II in Seattle, WA
pros:
Very stable employment.
Very lax environment.
11% retirement contribution without any required contribution from you!
$15 per month transit pass!
Annual campus BBQ with free food, drinks, games, music, etc.
Product shows every few weeks with tons of SWAG and free food.
cons:
Low pay due to non-forprofit.
Very short ladder to climb without a PHD.
No cheap lunch (dollar menu) within walking distance.

review_title: Great place to learn and thrive as a young researcher
pros:
- Warm, friendly environment 
- Top-notch research equipment and facilities 
- Research center located in a safe, beautiful location of South Lake Union
- Very academic atmosphere, free lectures and seminars given daily
cons:
- Hard to move up unless you have an MD or PhD
- Cutting of funding/grants can be very risky to keep your position long-term

job_title: Research Technician III in Seattle, WA
pros: Great place to work straight out of college! Started out as a Research Technician I, but was quickly promoted to a Research Technician II, then III within a year and half of working there. Was allowed to research my own project, and gained valuable skills working with mice, IHC, ELISA, qRT-PCR, etc.
cons: None! I absolutely loved my time there. Especially beer hour. Free beer every Friday, can't turn that down!

pros: After a year of employment the Hutch contributes 7% of your salary to a retirement plan with no strings attached (i.e. no matching contribution on your end required).
cons: At times the availability of funds depends on the ability of your lab's principal investigator to submit proposals and secure grants money.

pros: Overall a great place to work. Research teams genuinely and diligently pursue cures and knowledge. Work atmosphere is pleasant, calm and academic. There are bike commuter friendly facilities. And career change opportunities abound across the Center.
cons: Some systems and processes are outdated and taking a long time to update. High turnover in certain roles leaves gaps in projects. Parking and cafeterias on campus are expensive. There is an impossibly long waitlist for childcare.

pros: Company mission, benefits, campus atmosphere all contribute to a great overall company feel, and the people who join all have the same mindset of eliminating disease and improving human health
cons: Can be political at times and therefore makes it slightly difficult to accomplish things occasionally, but not anything over the top that would make it seem like a hard place to work at.

pros:
-Management relationship: manager is easily accessible and always makes time to speak with staff.
-Encouragement for advancement.
-Great work culture: RTT staff is a great group, smaller work organization that allows you to build relationships with all co-workers.
- Pay is great and PTO (30 days)
-Parking is inexpensive
cons: - Only suggestion I have it to implement an ORCA pass with the benefits.

job_title: Clinical Research- Administrative Division in Seattle, WA
pros: Mission and researchers trying to make a difference in cancer patient's lives.
cons: Limited resources so employees are over-worked. Limited benefits that continue to cost employees more out of pocket with minimal cost of living increases. Poor mid-level management.

job_title: Cancer Information Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Good variation on hours and good benefits. The location is in South Lake Union but is not on the main campus of Fred Hutch The Cancer information Specialist are isolated from the rest of the Fred Hutch campus.
cons: No career development or advancement opportunities. The supervisors and management have been in their positions to long, they are not open to suggestions or changes in protocol.

review_title: Fat Cats at the top shockingly similar to Wall Street
pros:
*Some genuinely dedicated folks working toward curing cancer. 
*Above average benefits package.
*Great resume builder if you want a career in biomedical research or medicine.
cons:
*Unfair compensation: I work in HR and was shocked to learn how much managers, specially upper management make while many support staffs make below industry salary. 
*Difficult funding environment makes for worrisome employment security unless you're in management. I have yet to see a manager fall victim to layoff or attrition.
*Some horrific managers building their own fiefdom. Crying employees at the HR office is not uncommon.

job_title: Research Technician I in Seattle, WA
pros: The Fred Hutchinson Cancer resesarch center is an amazing place to work, generous benefits with tons of holidays and lots of sick time.  Great facilities, with lots of experienced staff.
cons: Each lab is run individually therefore salaries are contingent on grant funds...makes it hard to get a raise.  All of the PI's have different styles of running a lab...some are better than others.  I have found that the stand off approach is hard in a lab, as there is no accountability for some people.

review_title: The Hutch is an excellent place to work.
job_title: Project Manager II in Seattle, WA
pros: The people at the Hutch are, almost to the person, deeply committed, hard working, highly intelligent and very rewarding colleagues.  I have grown tremendously at this institution.
cons: There are very few cons to share.  Perhaps two things:  the Hutch doesn't pay nearly as well as a for-profit company would.  The Hutch is also, because of Federal funding, somewhat at the mercy of the whims of the Congressional budget process.

review_title: FHCRC: A good place to work and learn....
pros: The Hutch is a very collegial atomosphere, generally the atomosphere is laid back although it is by no means a place for slakers; ther is an emphasis on getting quality data that can withstand scrutiny etc.
cons: The one bad things about the Hutch is that the expectations can make you feel like you're always under pressure.

review_title: Exciting research but lack of oversight in many cases
pros: Cutting edge technologies, wide variety of research fields, multinational employee base, some ability to create long-term positions if motivated and skilled, diverse career opportunitites
cons: Communication between groups and research areas could be improved, lack of details for career advancement, a fair number of long-time employees that have become 'stagnant', language and cultural barriers are sometimes present. Academia-level pay is not sustainable in my position.

review_title: Great Place to Learn and Grow
pros: Great Work culture and benefits. Amazing place to learn new skills and broaden your professional horizons.
cons: Inconsistency among PI's when it comes to management style, so each individual research lab has its own micro-culture. Not necessarily bad, but it's hard to compare one lab to another within the broader scope of the organization.

review_title: Wish it would have been 5 star
pros: Great Benefits, mostly daytime hours with few weekends in general.  Wonderful cafeteria.  Nice parking garages.  Easy to get to from freeway.
cons: Individual labs within Hutch function as individual units, and experiences will vary depending upon individual lab you are working for.  HR apparently cannot help you transfer or relocate to another lab if you come to them with a problem...of course you can apply for open positions in other labs like everybody else.  My experience was 1 star, but in the right lab at the Hutch the experience can be 5 star.  Ask LOTS of questions at your job interview to get a feel for the lab/supervisor.

pros: An organization with Great Mission provides a sense of contributing to the society. Good benefits with flexible hours. Work-life balance is possible depending on the department and the PI. People in general are easy going. Biking culture. Opportunities are provided through invited speakers to keep with current research.
cons: Not enough funding to staff adequately, pay can be better to attract and retain better candidates.  Limited advancement if you don't have PhD.

review_title: Great place full of hard-working people
pros: People are rewarded for working hard. I observed multiple people navigate their way up through progressively challenging positions taking on increasing responsibility each step of the way.
cons: Being a large organization with multiple departments and many layers, there are two downsides. First, problem staff have a tendency to stick around much longer than they might in a leaner organization. Second, it is particularly challenging to enact bold changes; there are inherent incentives to thinking small and incrementally.

pros: Good benefits, nice atmosphere (although depends on the lab), good location, child care center on grounds, great cafeterias, and coffee bars.
cons: Poor support from HR department, salaries are mediocre at best, child care center has very limited capacity = waiting for months to get a spot. Parental leave not paid and only standard 12 weeks.

review_title: Nice place to work. Loads of friendly,helpful people and a beautiful campus.
pros: Good pay and benefits plan. Super onsite coffee and cafeteria. Excellent library. Super cheap gym membership at 24Hour Fitness. Most people are open to chat, will help you with your work and are very nice, very smart people. It's great to work with like minded people and feel like one is making a difference.
cons: Work-life balance may not exist in some research groups.

pros: Company puts a focus on employee work-life balance better than any company I have worked for. Working for a non-profit research facility this well established is also a big plus. Not to mention eradicating the world of cancer (as well as other diseases) is a heck of a company cause, and Fred Hutch is making great strides.
cons: Compensation for some work is not as much as other tech companies in Seattle, but still very respectable. Social work environment is getting better, but still needs work.

review_title: Fantastic science, fantastic community, a really amazing place to work
job_title: Research Technician II in Seattle, WA
pros: The Hutch is an awesome place to work. Great colleagues, great access to resources and equipment needed to conduct research. Engaging and driven community at the forefront of scientific discoveries. Great benefits, beautiful location next to South Lake Union.
cons: Experiences vary depending on the lab you are working in. Some labs, funding may be a bit more tight depending on the financial state of that lab. Labs generally receive their funding from outside means.

review_title: Work Study Student Assistant plus full time summer
pros: Opportunity for lab experience as a Student. Worked hard and was rewarded with a full time job in the summer with more responsibilities. Learned how to do dna extraction and pcr. Opportunities to attend lectures on a wide range of subjects such as cancer 101 and new technology such as droplet pcr.
cons: lower salary then working in the private industry, the position is more to do with basic maintenance of the lab/office work rather than research.

review_title: Great place to learn and be involved in something that can change the world
pros: Great atmosphere and positive learning environment. Creativity and hard work is encouraged and rewarded. Great staff and working environment, very comfortable.
cons: Slower work environment, very relaxed which is preferred by some people, this also depends on what you are doing and where you are working.

pros: the work-life balance is great. Hutch has its own in-site daycare (expensive but good). The working atmosphere is great, but it is very dependent on your lab/
cons:
There is no commitment to postdocs to advance in their career in any way if you want to make a career at the Hutch. There are a lot of seminars if you want to go somewhere else though.
The pay depends very much in your lab, and usually postdocs salaries are ridiculously low.

review_title: Great place to work. Easy to stay for a long time.
pros: Working for the Administration arm of the institution allows for a relaxed pace of work. Most departments understand the value of private life and working at odd hours is usually not necessary.
cons: The academic pace of work can sometimes seem to slow to a crawl. There isn't much verticality to most departments, so advancement isn't really a thing (though they understand that is a problem and are working to solve it).

pros: Great scientific teams who have high standards, positive attitudes, and integrity. Working for the best goals with the best scientists.
cons: Business development team is comprised of difficult personalities, managing by shame and blame, and untrustworthy executives.

pros: Relatively laid back and relaxed culture (It's Seattle). Great mission.
cons: Managers are hit and miss. I have worked with some of the best managers and some of the worst in my time at Fred Hutch.

review_title: As a tech, vet the labs before joining
pros:
Cutting edge and highly sophisticated research

Admirable mission (To cure cancer)

highly open and collaborative science (may vary depending on department)
cons:
The PI was highly abusive and had unreal expectations 

Was way to political for anything to get done

No advancement opportunities for technicians

pros: Lots of hardworking good people here.  There are scientific and medical advancements being made.
cons: One of the divisions is run poorly.  Lots of attrition in this division, and staff are not valued.  Some of the management do not know what they're doing.  Ask a lot of questions and compare divisions before joining.

pros: There are lots of smart and nice people to work with, and there are lots of education opportunities like seminars and workshops. Hutch has a very beautiful campus and assigns individual office to many employees.
cons: The only complain I have is that the pay is not that great.

pros: Great mission. Organization is organized, methodical.  Some good perks as well as excellent reinforcement to the mission of a cure for cancer.
cons: High turnover in the development department.  The organization and lack of accountability and unity of individual entities within development leads to distrust and inequality.  I would never recommend working here.

review_title: Great mission to be a part of
pros: A great mission, so many opportunities to be a part of process improvement as they look to apply best practices, get to really leave your employee foot print.
cons: Some internal politics like any company of this size. There is a mix of leaders, some good some not great.

pros: I have enjoyed my time at the Proton Center. Doing what is right by the patient is always priority. They are committed to ensuring  patients get the right type of treatment, even when that means protons aren't medically the best therapy for them.
cons: There are a few weekends that the center is open for treatment.

pros: Nothing worth mentioning. The campus is pretty.
cons: I have a hard time believing half of these positive reviews are real.  Some of the worst people I've ever met work here. Stay away from VIDD - toxic work environment! Staff is treated like second class citizens. They use you up and then toss you like garbage when they become bored with you.

pros: Good benefits, nice physical space. Great location near Lake Union.  Salaries are above average. There is an on-site child care center (Hutch Kids).  Work-life balance is good, and most managers support telecommuting and flexible schedules, so long as you get the work done.
cons: Can be difficult to commute to given the traffic in south Lake Union with the new (crappy) infrastructure and influx of Amazon employees.

pros: Great resources if you are in a position to use them. Some really fantastic research going on.
cons: Labs are dependent on grant funding - if they go down (or if you aren't bringing in your own), you go down.  Support seems lab-dependent, and things can get isolating if you aren't outgoing.

pros: great supporting environment, meeting other people, helping people and the world, no backstabber, great coworkers, your work would always be appreciated, free classes.
cons: low salary, low budget, uncertainty on most of the things, working with sick people, parking fee, hard to move up in ladder

pros:
Decent pay for non-profit sector
Great benefits
Supportive, family-friendly environment
Wonderful, caring colleagues
Resources readily available
Incredible organizational history with lifetime careers across scientific/administrative division
cons:
Lack of formal training for management
Mundane performance review process that lacks teeth
Environment is sometimes too nice with under-performing colleagues not ushered out

pros: Highly supportive work environment with great collaboration. Excellent resources for advancement and improvement of skills. Benefits and healthcare are also a major plus.
cons: Work ethic could be a little more intensive - too many people seem to have the outdoors on their mind as opposed to working hard.

pros: Good mission and most people really like working at the Hutch
cons: This review is specific to OSR: highly micromanaged, favorites are treated better than others, certain people are promoted and given offices over others, no one in a management or lead role can make a decision to save their lives and overall, everyone is underpaid compared to other institutions.

pros: The people working on the front lines of patient care are phenomenal. Seeing patients graduate and go through recovery is very rewarding.
cons: The management is terrible. The CEO, Annika, is by far the most reckless, irresponsible CEO and should not be leading a healthcare organization. There is no board that she reports to, which means she has no one holding her accountable for her actions. She doesn't accept constructive feedback, and creates an extremely toxic work culture where people are afraid to voice their concerns or express new ideas. She is part of the reason why they are facing bankruptcy.

job_title: Project Manager II in Seattle, WA
pros: To work with a nonprofit who helps people struggling with cancer.
cons:
Hired off the internet by a (former, nolonger there, asked to leave) manager who recruited me. They hired someone else but 6 months later, came back asking for another interivew so I did and got the job in thier Statistical Research Center. My manager would tell me to get to know all the software apps he had developed, yet wouldn't give me access codes so I would fail. He enjoyed telling me I was "stupid" every day. I have a masters degree and an amazing resume and am not stupid. 

When I appealed to other colleagues, they appeared to be afraid of him. He would tell us (3 person team) which way our chairs were supposed to face when we walked out of the office. Even though Fred Hutch has a huge assortment of classes, I was denied attending any, ever, althoug I was FTE. When interviewed (and this was twice) I stated I did NOT do software dev, and the then manager assured me that since he and our colleague were devs, I would never have to do it. When I walked out, I had 6 software dev assignements. I even hired a tutor but software dev was nowhere to be found in the job description. NONE.

When I quit, upper management (no one is there anylonger, all fired) intstructed met to take my meticulous documentation to the hilarious Fred Hutch HR. I called and emaild for 7 business days before  I realized they had no intention of ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, getting back. I brought a member of Seattle's local TV consumer protection team with me to collect my things. This manager has since been fired. I conferred with the person who was in this job before me, and he revealed that this same manager had physically threatened him, into giving the manager a great annual review.

Insane. Unfair. Illegal. Avoid Fred Hutch by all means. It looks good on paper, but the abuse level is so high there, it is best to let their shareholders try and houseclean the abuseres before going in there. Not a safe place. NOT.

review_title: Get rid of longtime admin employees
job_title: Administrative Assistant I in Seattle, WA
pros: Working for a world renown institution. Good benefits. Good working conditions as far as the facilities. Ability to move up with the institution.
cons: People who have been there for years in admin positions are often gotten rid of so they can be replaced by someone paid less.

pros: Great people, lots of opportunities to work on important scientific advances. Retirement benefit is very good and other benefits are pretty good.
cons: At times, the political environment among faculty is pretty toxic, and you do not want to become a pawn in these games. Salaries are too low.

pros: Amazing mission, great people, 401k plan amazing (contribution model - automatic 7% of your salary after one year), lots of sick leave, 15 holidays, PTO, and personal days. Great leaders/management. Parking is cheap compared to other Seattle companies. Cheap ORCA pass
cons: No maternity or paternity leave. Sometime organization can feel a little outdated as far as process, technology, etc. No gym, cafetria/food is not very good (options minimal and not healthy).

review_title: Great place, stellar research, international leader in cancer and HIV research
pros: Exceptionally high research quality. Employees who are committed to the mission.  A good place to build a solid career.
cons: Lower salaries because it’s non-profit, so lose some people to industry.

review_title: Satisfied but there has got to be better places to work if you want to get paid well
pros: good benefits.  Good location.  Nice facilities.  Laid back atmosphere in some departments
cons: Salary compensation is barely inflation.  You really get the run around from HR when you try to get a raise or promotion.

review_title: I have never worked at a place that has a better culture than this - I love this place!
pros: Fred Hutch has an incredible mission - saving lives through research - but beyond that, it is an amazing community of employees and volunteers who love what they do and support one another.
cons: I wish more people knew about the Center so that it could be better funded by donations.

review_title: Doing cutting edge research at Fred Hutchinson
pros: Relative flexible working hours and feel good about doing world class research on cancer
cons:
less pay and lot of over time not because you are forced to do so but to keep in the front line in research it is not a 9-5 job any more. 
Federal funding is an issue and lot of labs are closing due to lack of funding

review_title: Everything is fine...when they value your department
pros: Benefits are awesome (200 hrs of sick time a year and amazing medical as a single person through Group Health), on-site parking (there is a fee), nice people to work with
cons: Management undervalues the Shared Resources Division and getting a promotion or an increase in hours is nearly impossible since they have to go through a review board for all positions, not just faculty.

pros: Valuable access to great minds, cutting edge research, and enjoyable coworkers and management. A wonderful opportunity to become acquainted with and be a part of the details of research in my field.
cons: Much lower pay than you'd expect, even for a part-time position and definitely much lower than it should be for Seattle's skyrocketing cost of living. I feel this really contributed to increased turnover in the position.

pros: Excellent mission, science, people and campus. Retirement benefit is great.
cons: growing pains, conficts between long term employees and new, admin systems are dated and challenging, org structure can be inhibiting. Benefits (aside from retirement) need to be updated. salaries can be low for non-scientific staff. Career paths for non-science gets no attention.

review_title: Wonderful mission but acts more like a sorority
pros: AWESOME benefits and work/life balance (depends on your team)
cons: Cut throat. They don't promote within because of internal politics. They act more like a sorority.  They would prefer to have all of their friends come work for their team even though they don't necessarily have the experience.

job_title: Animal Care Technician in Seattle, WA
pros: Respectable place but cheap surprising.
cons:
Not new employee helpful. Campus has the feel of a college campus NOT a place of employment. Very dissassocted with its employees. New employee orient 2 months later.
New employee paperwork unable to download and submit.password for Xerox machine are you kidding.parking takes 2 months to get

pros:
Flexible hours
Commitment to mission evident in each department
Comparable compensation to other non-profits
On campus dining
Good benefits and healthcare plan options available
Offers unlimited Orca card for monthly fee
cons:
On campus parking is expensive and limited
Daily street parking options are extremely limited and expensive
Difficult to get to campus via bus only - limited bus routes to/from campus
Maternity leave options are limiting for newer employees

pros: Relaxed workplace, coworkers are easy to get along with, good location, good money, good benefits; just an overall great place to work.
cons: It can be hard to move up, and the politics in some other parts of the organization aren't that great.

job_title: Statistical Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: I have been here for 3 months, and so far it has been a great experience.  My group is friendly and willing to let me learn the data at my own pace.
cons: The only real con I have so far, is that the salary is quite a bit lower than comparable positions.

job_title: Cancer Information Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: I loved the great team environment. This department has very supportive management and career development. Good benefits package--PTO, 401K, employee appreciation.
cons: There was little room for advancement in this department. The job could get repetitive.

review_title: A great way to make a difference.
pros:
Good pay, excellent benefits, excellent employee support.
Very friendly culture.  Rewarding to feel like you are making a difference.
cons: Lab supervisors not well trained in management and motivation.  Poor mobility for non-PhDs.

pros: Benefits and forgiveness to your own personal life circumstances. They allow so much for self and family. Awesome environment
cons: Pay isn't the best. Leadership is a bit lackluster. You shouldn't really have someone who belongs behind a microscope a leadership position. People skills don't really mix well.

pros: The cafeteria is pretty nice, but it’s expensive.
cons:
Benefits are not great.
Terrible, elitist, snobby culture.
Low pay with no opportunities for advancement.
Horribly long hours and zero work-life balance.  You will have no life if you work at Fred Hutch.

pros: People have a sense and attitude of purpose and it's infectious. You know that the cause everyone that's working for is greater than yourself.
cons: They're IT department is going through tons of changes and shakeups. It's a normal part of moving things forward but people tend to get lost in the shuffle.

pros: Flexible work schedule with the availability to work when works best. Great staff and coworkers who are always there to boost morale. Great environment to work that fosters creative and diverse research opportunities.
cons: Trying to move from a per diem job to a full time job is difficult. Being per diem is not cool because of lack of benefits or job security

pros: Great benefits if you are part of the "faculty", not as good (still good) if you are classified as "staff". Great, smart people to work with. Relaxed atmosphere
cons: Difficult to grow out of a given post. Salaries can be low considering how expensive Seattle is.

review_title: FHCRC DOES NOT TREAT LONGTERM EMPLOYEES WELL
pros: In the beginning they allowed for personal growth, training and more.  After 24 years the leadership allowed management to do things that were ethically wrong
cons: Directors hired with no management experience

review_title: I am a current research technician, just graduated from the Uw.
job_title: Research Technician I in Seattle, WA
pros: Good company moral. People are very kind and they hire great people.
cons: Management is individually based so you can end up in a very stressful environment and it has nothing to do with this company.

pros: Allows flexibility in work hours, good benefits and diversity in the company, environmental and health conscious work place, good commute options
cons: working from home is not supported, no group discussions happen within the group for advancing in the career or the position

pros: Many eminent folks in medicine/basic sciences and public health. Good access to seminars and talks by people well known in their areas of research.
cons: Slow to embrace technology.  Individual labs and so harder to form multi-disciplinary teams. Many jobs there funded on soft money

job_title: Grant & Contract Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: I've been here for about five years. To this day, I really feel that I'm working my dream job. Great location, great benefits, great cause. However, it really depends on the department you work in. I'm really lucky to be with a team of great manager and colleagues.
cons: can't think of any now

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Nice place to work, good benefits, a lot of opportunities for training
cons: The work load really depends on which lab/ department you are working in.  Don't hesitate in asking to former employees about their experience in the place where you are applying for.

review_title: Wonderful research center in an expensive city
pros: Great environment for academic research; many smart and wonderful people for collaboration; lots of research seminars; excellent core facility; overall a very nice place for research. Bonus, recently the center has opened an on-site clinic for employees
cons: Food is a bit overpriced; typical salary for a non-profit organization; career advancement is limited.

pros: Collaborative caring and exciting workplace.  Employees are treated very well, great on site food and coffee stands. Most importantly, science driven and patient focused.
cons: Traffic congestion in the area and freeway entrances/exits. Longest part of my commute is often getting the one block from the parking garage to the mercer street freeway entrance.

review_title: It is easy to get comfortable
pros: Great collaborative work environment, and the facilities are top notch. As long as funding is available, all is good. The Hutch provides great benefits.
cons: Overall there is very little potential for advancement, it should be viewed as a stepping stone to somewhere else. Pay is comparatively very low.

pros: They do great work and have a lot of terrific people working there
cons: It is very political and the management in some areas are not good.

pros:
-Enriching, intellectual work environment
-Excellent benefits for non-profit work
-Training is offered in nearly any area you'd consider for personal and professional development
-Beautiful work space
-Great cafeteria
cons:
-salaries are lower than other similar work in different organizations
-your job satisfaction is highly dependent on your team

pros: Dedicated scientists and administrators, supportive work environment with good benefits, support for professional growth and mobility within the company
cons: Not all departments are created equally. The Hutch is huge so a great experience in one division doesn't mean it will be great in another. Seems obvious, but truthful.

review_title: Funding challenges, inexperienced management, toxic environment
pros: Cafeteria, some nice people, (false) sense of reputation by outside world
cons: Management responsibilities given to people without experience, focus on money - not quality data or performance, amazing this place hasn't imploded.  Relationships between departments is horrible, communication is absent and physicians are not held accountable.  The place is an accident wating to happen.  If the public knew how funding is wasted there would be hell to pay.

review_title: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center is a GREAT place to work
pros:
- Great flexibility in work hours and work environment 
- High expectations from employees while also having a big focus on quality of life
cons: - Sometimes difficult to move around

review_title: Excellent research environment with great benefits.
pros: Flexible work schedule, which will depend on where exactly you are working. Excellent benefits package and additional health programs. Atmosphere is fantastic and the campus setting is beautiful.
cons: Some labs can be difficult depending on the PI. Not really anywhere to advance to in research.

pros: In my time as an intern at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, I worked with some really brilliant people who were always eager to help.
cons: The traffic can be really bad in South Lake Union which makes it hard to get to/leave work sometimes. I wish that parking at work was more accessible.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Seattle, WA
pros: There are fantastic programs at Fred Hutch for postdoc career development. I am looking to transition from academia to biotech, there are fantastic networking opportunities and support system.
cons: Postdocs are always overworked and under paid. The stress level varies drastically between labs.

review_title: It was a good place until WAMU took over the IT department.
pros: The mission of the center is wonderful. Lots of smart people work here.
cons: IT department has lost its soul. Most managers are from WAMU so it's very corporate now. Instead of collaborative, it's adversarial between departments now.

pros: Good benefits, they have a "picnic" every year, security 24/7, a place to sit and enjoy the fireworks both on Independace Day and NYE
cons: It seems like most people have an attitude, but my supervisor and coworker were the biggest cons.

review_title: Toxic culture, could care less about administrative/operational staff
pros:
The organizations mission
Flexibility of hours
cons:
Faculty can do no wrong in the eyes of leadership (and they are wrong A LOT)
Treats administrative staff like they are replaceable and beneath the scientific staff
Faculty has no accountability for actions
Toxic Masculinity is EVERYWHERE
Hostile

job_title: Research Technician I in Seattle, WA
pros: Egalitarian atmosphere, laid back, friendly, beautiful campus
cons: Depending on the luck of who is your supervisor, your experience may vary.  Also, mays a bit less b/c it's a non-profit.

review_title: You left, then everything does not count
pros: some noble winner to brag
cons: My friend roported a descrimination against a female after his leave, and he was told NO ONE would contact him AGAIN as thati he was not working for them any more.

review_title: Interview process is as inefficient as the place itself
pros: easy interview and you just have to make them happy
cons: The interview process takes 8 months, and they do not contact you when they rejected you. It's not just rude, but unprofessional. The least they can do is to contact you when they don't think you are a good fit, but they'd keep you in the profile and give you hope, then reject you months later. It's a complete waste of time.

pros: Great to see the work the doctors and researchers do.  Staff is very motivated to find cures and care for people
cons: Unfriendly staff.  Unorganized on every level.  They give project managers multiple doctors that have no commonality.  They say they are flexible but not really.

review_title: Good experience to find out the ins and outs of a research lab
pros: Work/life balance, meaningful work, many extra resources for training.
cons: Can be somewhat clique-ish. Lab members are friendly towards one another but, there are so many labs at FHCRC.

pros: Great place to work. Cared about their employees. Wish I was still employed there.
cons: Made you pay for your ORCA card. It should really be a write off for the company.

pros: Great place to work. Everyone is friendly and passionate about their work. Many opportunities to advance. Regular work socials and work sponsored events on campus to enjoy
cons: Can be cliquey. Slow in hiring process. Located downtown so no parking and not on a direct bus line.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Seattle, WA
pros:
You can meet some scientists with wisdom and deep & broad knowledge.
Good postdoctoral services.
Convenience for transportation and downtown life.
cons: A few of Principle Investigators are very money-oriented and always proposal, funding, and publications.....I know it is tough for budge-limited, but research should be fun and will be funded.

job_title: Professional Support Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
There's a great work life balance and it's both inspiring and educational to be part of a vibrant research community.  Good number of paid holidays
Good health care/dental
cons:
The paid vacation time is just so-so.
There seems to be a nearly constant level of at least low-level reorganization within departments/divisions

pros: I worked here as a Research Assistant and absolutely love the Center. The work-life balance is great, the people are friendly and laid-back, the offices are beautiful. I left only because I was relocating.
cons: No cons that I could see.

pros: Great benefits & retirement package. Promoted career development thru seminars & workshops. Loved the location and access to transit. Encouraged healthy living through employee programs & cafeteria. Great cafe vita coffee!
cons: Child care extremely expensive & long wait list. Cafeteria was really expensive.

review_title: Good place to work, but low pay
pros:
-Awesome co-workers
-Great mission
-Helps the community
-Top of the line scientists
cons:
-AWFUL pay. A dollar over minimum wage when most of us have graduated college? Please. 
-No one ever gets back to you when you apply on their website, even as a current employee.

review_title: It was a wonderful place to work
pros:
Easy commute if you live nearby south lake union in Seattle
Great benefits
Big promoters of healthy life style
Great facilities
Great people
Good work-life balance
cons: Sometimes it is difficult to interact/collaborate with people beyond your own group

pros: Flexible hours, very nice and friendly co-workers, beautiful office and neighborhood, free parking on weekends, weekdays 10 hour metered street parking available
cons: The job nature is pretty boring, but luckily supervisors let you train on other stuff once you get a hand on what you are working on.

pros: Employees committed to the mission of researching cancer and infectious diseases, which in turn creates an inclusive, positive work culture.
cons: The more Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center grows, the more time and effort must be spent on peripheral issues due to such a large organization.

pros: Friendly company to work for.
cons: Depending on the PI who manages you, you'll be worked to death. Or chastised when you want to work a regular 40 hour work week rather than the expected 60+ hours.

job_title: Systems Analyst/Programmer IV in Seattle, WA
pros: largely depends on what group you're in. good benefits, nice campus, good work-life balance
cons: when i was there they weren't embracing telecommuting as much as similar industries, pay is a tad lower

review_title: Can be a great place to work
pros: Amazing community, interesting work, great mission, lovely campus, nice benefits, laid back and supportive environment, very smart people
cons: Salaries can be lower than average, sometimes administrative infrastructure lacking but getting better

review_title: More interested in social standing than work
pros: Good business goal, innovative research.
cons: Some groups are micromanaged by people who are more interested in social connections than producing excellent work.    Groups do NOT want to work together, too much in-fighting to make progress on studies.  HR is not your friend, they are simply there to bolster managers no matter what.  I have never worked in a place that fired so many people so often for ridiculous reasons.

review_title: Great mission, but little chance for upward mobility
pros: Contributing to the research to prevent and cure cancer was personally very fulfilling. Most of my team members were great to work with.
cons: Tight deadlines which require over time. It is a very stressful work environment. Low chance for upward mobility.

review_title: Great place to develop skills and get published
job_title: Research Technician II in Seattle, WA
pros: I love working here. Great Science, great people. I've learned so much working here. Relaxed atmosphere. Good Benefits.
cons: Its a tough place to stay is if you don't have a PhD. Limited resources for career development. Pay is not competitive.

review_title: I worked here for a little over a year and really enjoyed it. If it was in my area of interest I would love to come back
pros: Great environment and you're doing great work. Working along side researchers and scientists.
cons: The job can get a little repetitive.

pros: Intelligent colleagues, beautiful campus, and excellent resources are just some of the many reasons that it's nice to work at FHCRC.
cons: Pay can be an issue, especially given the rising cost of living in Seattle

pros:
- Meaningful high impact projects
- Talented faculty, administration,  grants and finance teams
- Professional atmosphere
- Excellent training resources
- Vertical advancement dependent on team
-  Good benefits
- Great campus
cons:
- Employee equitably
- Traffic
- Caffeteria food cost

review_title: I have worked there 18 years and am proud to say so. Excellent organization committed to improving lives.
pros: Management strives to ensure employees have a good work life balance. Excellent benefits.
cons: Salaries aren't always competitive.

pros: good benefits, great working environment, seattle has nice weather compared to other cities on the east coast. that's about all I can come up with.
cons: low salary as a postdoc, considering how expensive the city is. located close to downtown so living is expensive.

review_title: Great atmosphere and shared Resources. Know your boss.
pros: Fred Hutch provides good health care and an on-site employee clinic. People work reasonable hours.
cons: The salary is not thrilling and researcher salaries are not negotiable. Make sure to know your future boss and colleagues before accepting a position.

pros: The hours are good and the people are wonderful.
cons: Some weekend work and there can be rude people sometimes.

pros: Great mentors, close ties with the university. Mentors have less various responsibilities and are usually more tied n with their labs.
cons: Farther away than university labs

review_title: One of the best places to do science, and not just cancer research!
pros: The quality of the science at the Fred Hutch is amazing and people are very humble about it.
cons: I can't say anything negative about the Fred Hutch.

pros: Great place to work at, they care about employees
cons: They do require you to know almost everything for the job you applied, so if you were thinking of learning something new, they would not choose you.

review_title: Established Research Center Needs to Shake The Dust
pros: Excellent research environment, personnel, and connections to other institutions and industry.
cons: Often slow and unpredictable funding environment. Could be more efficient. Investment in computing resources and training needs to be better.

review_title: Overall a great company to work for
pros:
Good work/life balance
Really good retirement plan
cons: Pay could be better; there should be more standardization across teams. Each team is managed very differently depending on who the project manager is, which creates inconsistencies.

review_title: A door that never stops spinning around
pros: Bone marrow transplant by Dr Thomas decades ago.  There are some very nice people but a majority lack any real skills.  They wouldn't survive anywhere else.
cons: Scientist with huge egos wasting government funds and funds from local community.  Riding on tail of Bone marrow transplant.

job_title: Post Doctoral Researcher in Seattle, WA
pros: In general the Science is top notch at this institute.
cons: Horrible PI that's made his name based on post doc ideas/grants.

pros: It depends what lab you are working in. My lab is a great place to work. Friendly scientist. We help each other with experiments. A lot of opportunity to learn new techniques.
cons: Low salary. Most interns don't get paid at all.

pros: Great benefits and access to great opportunities around campus.
cons: Leadership is lacking and take a long time to come to a decision.  A lot of talk and no action.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Seattle, WA
pros: Great compensations,  (poor salary) great people. Amazing research of high standards. True organization of shared resources is amazing. A great place to advance and do great science
cons: Few if any opportunities to go further than postdoctoral researcher. Salaries are low for postdocs.

review_title: Members and Staff Dedicated to Curing Disease and Doing Great Science
pros: There's always something new to learn between the seminars and training opportunities available.
cons: Upward career trajectory position dependent.  It's academia, so don't expect industry pay.

pros: Great community and resources (i.e. Post-doc society, help with transitioning to careers in industry, resume/CV help, etc. . .)
cons: It would be great if the company had more diversity (The Hutch United group is working towards this)

pros: Patients come first. Management is supportive of staff. My coworkers are smart, engaged, and fun to be around. It feels like family.
cons: Young company growing rapidly, but worth it.

pros: I loved the environment and the division I worked in. Everyone was helpful and invested in me building my career. Great place for young researchers to start off at!
cons: Hard to move outside of division. Everything is very very siloed.

review_title: Overall it was a good experience, great people to work with
pros: Benefits are great, office culture is relatively laid back.
cons: Expensive to park at work, childcare options are too expensive for the average worker

job_title: Director of Content & Platform in Seattle, WA
pros: Organization is poised to make incredible advancements in cancer treatments and therapies.
cons: Sprawling work force and different, disparate areas of expertise make central services for Fred Hutch a challenge.

pros: Good mission, many people seem to like working here
cons: Most researchers here are funded by grants, which can lead to a somewhat toxic environment (competition between researchers/not much collaboration, more senior researchers exploiting those just out of school). Lots of office politics, and not much flexibility with work schedule (no option to work from home).  However, it's important to note that experiences vary wildly depending on which group you work with.

review_title: Top science, high-caliber employees, good benefits
pros: I had a terrific experience.  I was treated respectfully as a scientist and given independence which allowed me to grow intellectually.  Benefits and compensation were excellent.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

pros: At the time, I had understanding, positive, and hardworking managers. Unique group of people doing a unique job.
cons: During the last few months of my time there, there was a massive reorg and some great people ended up leaving.

review_title: What you see is what you get
pros: Access to various ongoing trainings and presentations through Fred Hutch.
cons: No room for growth. Maybe one person has gotten another position directly from this position.

review_title: A nice job if you don’t mind following a lot of rules
job_title: Cancer Information Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Nice co-workers, meaningful work, good benefits, varied job responsibilities
